projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: POEMS AND TRANSLATIONS, WRITTEN Upon everal Occaions, AND To everal Perons. By a late Scholar of Eaton.

q.l: Et nos ergo manum ferulae ubduximus, & nunc
Expectes eadem Ã ummo minimoque Poeta:
Scripimus, & tulta est clementia, cum tot ubique
Vatibus occurras, periturae parcere chartae.

div.q: Non illud ipum quod optimum et deperandum, & in praetantibus rebus, magna unt ea, quae unt optimis proxima; prima enim equentem, honetum et, in ecundis, tertiique conitere. Tull.
div.p: LONDON: Printed for Henry Bonwicke, at the Red Lion in St. Paul's Church-Yard. 1689.
TO The Right Honourable THE Countes of CLARENDON, THESE Rude and npolih'd Poems Are Humbly Preented, DEDICATED, and DEVOTED By the Author, Her Ladyhip's Mot Dutiful and Obedient Servant.

div.head: TO THE Worthy Mr RODERICK, Upper-Mater OF EATON-SCHOOL.
div.l: THee Trifles at Your Feet I'd humbly lay,
And gladly thee for my vat Debts repay;
I'd beg the great Protection of Your Name,
To have that Altar anctifie my Flame:
My little All, lent Stock I would reign,
With reaon, proud to erve at uch a Shrine;
But that they're Trifles all, and all thoe Trifles mine.
Admit them moderate: the Seed that's own,
At firt was Yours, much more the Crop's Your own.
You gave the Talent, that improv'd I bring;
By You my Chirping Mue was taught to ing.
You warm'd my Soul with new Promethean Fire,
Your Wings my flagging Thoughts learnt to apire.
You all the Wheels of my low Fancy move,
My doubtful Wit at Your true Touch-tone prove.
My Pegaus was in Your Pature bred,
Not on coare Birch, but Buds of Ivy fed.
Hail the profes'd Palaemon of our Ile!
Aetonian Helicon for every tile!
Now give me leave thee my Firt-fruits to bring,
Pledge of the Summer, and the Pride of Spring.
So Primroes are upon Altars laid;
And Pepper-corns for Rent by Beggars paid.

div.head: A Tranlation out of Syneius.
< in non-Latin alphabet > , &c.
div.l: WIT, alas, what idle Charms!
Herculean Strength, or Milo's Arms!
Beauty, what ground for Pride is there?
Or Gold, as trifling as the Fair!
What Halcyons build within a Crown?
What olid Pleaure's in Renown?
If in an equal Ballance laid,
And by a hand impartial weigh'd,
With erious and Divine affairs,
With holy and Religious cares,
Compar'd with the Almighty's Love,
Lighter than Vanity they'll prove.
One eaily outtrips in coure,
The bet that ever back'd a Hore;
Can ride Bucephalus full peed,
Or one of Neptune's generous Breed:
Can make his fiery Courer fly,
Like winged Lightning, through the Sky.
Another has prodigious tore,
Mountains and Seas of Golden Ore;
The Mier's heart could wih no more.
Whom Midas envying, would prevent,
And of his econd wih repent.
One is a Cretan at his Bow,
Can hoot a very Hair in two;
Excels the Mater of this Art,
Makes Teucer lay it deep to heart;
And what was formerly his Pride,
His Bow, as ueles, throw aide.
Another has a comely Face;
(And when there's Beauty in the cae,
What Spell can lay this Spirit? what Charms
Of humane power reit thee Arms?)
H'as uch a Beauty o divine,
Nireus his Title would reign,
And emulous Narcius pine.
Another prides in Noble Bloud;
Another in a numerous Brood
Of lovely Girls and hopeful Boys,
Their Countries Props, and Parents Joys;
Of Danaus and Aegyptus Stock,
A great and a well-order'd Flock.
This is my Wih, (let them have theirs,
Which are the leat of all my cares,)
Let me live private and obcure,
From Noie, and Pride, and Scorn ecure;
From the drie Complements of Court,
Glitning Glo-worms! Fortunes port!
From mean Ambition, lying Fame,
Bae Actions, and a tainted Name.
No fine-pun Cobwebs of the Great,
No gay Contrivances of State:
No gilded Greatnes, empty hows,
(Mi-guiding Meteors!) make me loe
That happy Path that I would choe.
Let me with Aglaus be found,
Pleas'd in my little pot of ground;
Or blet with the poor Gardner's fate,
Envied by Alexander's tate.
Abdolonymus, only known
To ome poor Pot-herbs of his own;
Gardner, degraded to a Throne!
What if the World hould never hear
Of uch a one as Goâl there?
On Earth let me a Cypher be,
So I make one, my God, with thee.
Here let me, as a tranger, live,
At bet a nameles Expletive;
So to my elf I am but known,
And unto thee, my God, alone.

div.head: ODE I. Love.
div.l: AS lately on my leepy Bed
I laid my ick and drowie head,
And Night it elf with me lay dead
The Heavens nodded, Nature nor'd,
When Winking Morpheus gave the word
Silence; and at the Court of Night
'Twas time to hang out every Light:
Now wearied Limbs took their repoe,
When troubled Minds began to doe;
When twinkling Stars could hardly keep
Themelves from dropping fat aleep;
Some dimm'd and hot, but others fell:
Cloe was the ilence, deep as Hell.
Half the Creation joyntly lept,
Clouds Sympathetick Showers wept.
The Moon, like all the ret, was gone
To Bed to her Endymion.
Cupid knock'd at Anacreon's Gate;
What buines have you here o late,
Said I? and ask'd the tranger's name,
His Meage, and from whence he came
Poor little Beggar-boy, aid he,
That is benighted; pity me:
For Heaven's ake, Sir, let me in,
For I am almot wet to th' skin:
I've been a hooting all this day;
'Tis dark, and I have lot my way:
The Stars themelves, the very Moon,
Share my Misfortune; I'm undone!
Let me but in a Stable lie,
'Twill be a deed of Charity.
I heard the flattering Racal peak,
And could not but for pity's ake,
In uch a cae, open the Gate,
Which traight my Youngter enter'd at,
With Bag and Quiver at his back:
And having drunk a Glas of Sack
To warm within, my little Squire,
I ask'd him to come near the Fire;
And brought him out a umptuous hoard
Of Victuals on a plenteous Board,
The bet my Houe could then afford;
And play'd the Courtier, to excue
The barren deerts of my Mue
So poor a Meal as he mut make,
And wih'd it better for his ake.
I rub'd his little hands in mine,
And wrung his hair o oft, o fine,
Like his own Mother's Locks. And now
He look'd o charmingly, I vow
I carcely could forbear to hug
The little fiery wanton Pug.
And thus no little time was pent
In Ceremony and Complement.
Now when he found himelf grow warm,
Has the Rain done my Bow no harm,
(Said he)? and made no more to do,
But took his pretty little Bow,
And trung it up, and pierc'd my heart:
So does the Gad-bee's tickling mart
Fret and delight th' infected part.
Up and away then, Whip and Spur,
Crying, God b'ye, your Servant, Sir;
I wih you well, my Hot, adieu;
I'm very much oblig'd to you:
I ee my Bow is well enough;
But Friend, your Heart's not Arrow-proof.

div.head: ODE II. The Letter-Carrier.
div.l: TEll me, amiable Dove,
Thou great Embaadour of Love,
A Spokes man fit for amorous Jove;
Tell me, tell me, why uch hat?
Whither is't you flie o fat?
Where didt thou thy breath perfume?
From what Spicy Country come?
From whence, with thy Mercurial Wing,
Dot thou thee Heavenly Odours bring?
Swimming through th' ambitious Air,
Proud to kis thy Wings o fair,
Leaving a cent of weetnes there.
Tell me who it is, will be
So honour'd with thy companie?
The Dove replied, What would I give,
Poor Dove, for a Preervative
From Coxcombs o inquiitive?
Pray what are my concerns to you?
But ince 'tis your deire to know,
And Medlers will not be aid no:
(Save me, ye Gods; for what offence
Mut I be kill'd by Impertinence?)
I am (and then he curb'd her Head,
Her Tail, Fan-like, by Feathers pread,
And walk'd in tate, and clapp'd her Wings,
And did a hundred pretty things,
To hew her pride) Anacreon's Dove,
And manage the affairs of Love
With his Bathyllus, that dear Boy,
(Oh, happy tate that I enjoy!)
Lovely Bathyllus, he that can,
By one weet look, ev'n conquer Man;
Can by the Magick of his Eyes,
Over all things tyrannize;
Victorious Beauty of all Greece,
The whole Creation's Mater-piece;
The Pride of Nature, and the Fire
That raies Venus's Deire,
Whom thÃ´ he envy, he mut till admire;
Could make a Stoick change his mind,
Fixt as the Sun, turn like the Wind,
And in Love's School more Pleaures find,
Than in his former Hermite's Cell,
Principles dark and deep as Hell.
To Venus once I did belong,
She old me for a trifling Song.
O happy I, that us'd to run
From place to place, from Sun to Sun,
Managing the Intrigues of Love,
With Mars, and half the Gods above,
With her Seraglio of Gallants,
That by turns upply'd her wants;
Am Servant to Anacreon,
Who lov'd by all, yet loves but one.
And as you ee me now, I bear
His Letters to his lovely Fair;
This the perfume that cents the Air.
He promies to et me free;
Excue me for uch libertie:
No other freedom would I crave,
Than name and nature of a Slave;
Nor other lavery can I dread,
Than being, as he tells me, freed.
For to what purpoe hould I flie,
And ramble in the pacious Skie,
By Famine, Net, or Arrow die?
Sit tarving on a Mountains top,
Or coo on barren Trees, and hop,
In fear of death, from bough to bough,
I know not where, I know not how;
Either die for want of Meat,
Ele Haws, and Chaff, and Vetches eat:
Nor afety in that wretched fare,
'Ware Birdlime, Turtle! and the Snare.
Where Puddle-water is the bet,
A hollow Tree the oftet Net;
To hear Owls Muick, nor that long;
She'll make one dance unto her Song.
Is this the freedom I have lot?
Is this the freedom others boat?
I by my Mater now can tand,
Peck Crums out of Anacreon's hand;
And have my little Ganymede
To give me Wine, whene're I need.
I in a merry mood, can up
Wine out of Anacreon's Cup;
His own pure, choice, delicious Wine,
So mooth, o parkling, and o fine!
Which he keeps purpoely to treat
Bathyllus with, when they two meet.
When I get drunk, I clap my wings,
And dance, whilt my Anacreon ings.
And when I am a leepy grown,
Upon his Harp I lay me down:
Muick and I can there agree
In one united Harmonie;
Both make our Mater Melodie.
Peace and Concord is, in brief,
The perfect um of my whole Life,
Free from danger, noie, or trife.
Farewel. But now too late I mut repent,
That like your elf I'm grown impertinent:
For when I'm gone, you'll ay you took me wrong,
To be a Dove with a Crows pratling Tongue.

div.head: ODE III. Gold.
div.l: COuld the Miers heaps of Gold
Flatter Death to quit her hold;
Or would Hell be o content,
To take money for her Rent;
Could a man at any rate,
Bribe inexorable Fate;
Could he get Charon in the mind
To leave his Paengers behind,
When he has once his Earnet paid;
Could this Spirit be ever laid
By all the Magick and the Spells
Of Conjuring Miers in their Cells;
Would Mercury but load himelf,
Intead of men, with loads of Pelf;
Cumber up Hell with Bags of Coin;
Could he prevail with Proerpine:
'Twould be a notable Deign.
Could all his Wealth and all his Power
Purchae Repit for an hour,
O how I'd crape and drudge for Ore!
O how I'd ranack Natures Store!
And when I'd done, till crave for more.
I'd drein Pactolus for his Sands,
And wih for Midas Golden Hands:
I'd wah in Tagus to be rich,
Glad to have that Golden Itch.
The World hould erve me for a Mine,
To furnih me with Soveraign Coin,
And I would erve at Pluto's Shrine.
Almighty Gold hould be my Word,
Almighty Gold hould be my Lord:
Almighty Gold hould all controul;
I'd bear his Image in my Soul.
By him inpir'd, I'd eek and find
Wealth, the Saviour of Mankind.
For Gold is God, and omething more;
His Deity would I adore.
Of my God I'd make a hrine,
And out of that a God-head coin.
I'd dig to Hell, but that I'd get
Enough to pay the common Debt
Of Nature, a Securitie
From all Arrets, and thus et free,
That Hell and I might be at peace,
And Death might grant a longer Leae.
But if it be too hard a Task;
Nay, if it be a in to ask
The price of a few fleeting days,
To add a furlong to ones Race;
To change one pan of life to two,
A ingle Thread into a Clue;
To hire the Fates to heath the Knife,
With Gold to purchae longer life:
Why hould I by day-time weep,
Or in the night-time break my leep?
Why hould I beat my Breat, complain,
Sigh, and whine, and all in vain?
Melt into Tears, and tear my Hair,
Like one in frenzy or depair?
For if the Fates will o ordain,
That I mut die like other men;
Nor have I reaon to believe,
From Fate I hou'd my elf reprieve:
If I mut die, and hence be hurl'd
From this into another World;
What ue or pleaure can I have
Of Gold or Silver in the Grave?
They neither revel, buy nor ell,
Nor drink, nor dance, nor love in Hell.
Therefore I hope you will excue
Thee Recreations that I ue
Rarely, but Natural to my Mue.
Beides, I am not like to meet
A Mitris in a Winding-Sheet;
Or court a Pretty Maid to Bed
To Grave to me, when I am dead.

div.head: ODE IV. Grey Hairs.
div.l: WHither fliet thou, O my Dear,
And leav't a melting Lover here,
Dying, inking in Depair?
Is my Reverend Hoary Grey,
Such a Bug-bear in your way?
What makes you look o ghat, and tare
As if you're frightned at my Hair?
Becaue your elf's o wondrous fair?
Becaue your Cheeks, o lovely red,
Can make Aurora hide her head,
And bluhing run agen to bed?
Make baffled Venus loe her Trade,
The emulous Roes blat and fade?
Scarlet and Crimon loe their die,
Beauty it elf aham'd to vie?
Do not cornfully depie
Me, the Victim of your eyes;
But accept my bleeding Heart,
Weak in Nature, trong in Art.
Then all objections jutly mute
Will prove, our different colours uit.
For you mut own, to do me right,
I'm ne'er the wore for being white.
Such a lutre Lillies cat;
Wanton Roes, Lillies chat.
But when they both together meet,
The Rivals breathe a fragrant weet,
And make a Garland look compleat.

div.head: ODE V. Drink.
div.l: WHen Wine has fum'd into my head,
My buie Senes all lie dead,
And melancholy Megrims ink
Into the Ocean of my Drink:
This Whirl-pool wallows them all up;
And at the bottom of my Cup
I meet with all the Gods can give,
To make a Mortal happy live.
I never covet to be great,
Nor envy Croeus his Etate.
Like Bacchanal, I dance and ing,
And corn the Title of a King:
I make a Foot-ball of a Crown,
Kick glorious Diadems up and down.
I verifie Extempore,
And all my Speech is Poetrie.
So that with reaon I may think
I'm made of Poetry, Love, and Drink.
Let other men fall out, and fight
For true or for pretended Right,
To Arms, to Arms; I never care:
A Bottle's all the Arms I bear.
Serve only under Cupid's Banner,
Till made a Lord of Venus Mannour.
But now I think on't, I am told,
That now my youthful Bloud grows cold:
Be wie, Anacreon, as thou'rt old.
That Fate has ey'd me everal years,
Reolv'd to pay off all Arrears:
One foot is in the Grave, and Death
Would fain uck out my fragrant breath:
But I'll prevent him, and will lie
Dead drunk o'th' pot before I die;
And by this pretty Countermine
Baffle the Cannibal's Deign.

div.head: Anacreon's Bleing.
div.l: WHen Sleep had clos'd my weary Eyes,
Sleep, that Door of Myteries;
On wing'd Chimaera's traight convey'd,
Where Centinels of Viions play'd
Before the Gates of Night and Shade;
Arriv'd at pacious Fairy Land,
With Sibyl's Bough, and Morpheus Wand,
My Fancy on an Object wrought,
An Object worthy of a thought;
That which by day-time did engage
My mind in a Poetick Rage,
When all my Senes eal'd up, lay
Free from the buines of the day;
My roving Brains again puru'd,
(ThÃ´ the Conception was but rude)
And once again with Joy renew'd.
Methought Anacreon appear'd,
An old man with a Reverend Beard,
Old, yet had a graceful look;
With a Bottle and a Book;
His breath melt trong of fragrant Wine,
(Ah cured be the fatal Vine!)
His Lips with Kies worn, and drie,
His ruffled Cheeks of Scarlet die,
His Spaniel Cupid running by.
When by degrees he nearer drew,
My Face, my Gate, and Habit knew.
When falling protrate on the ground,
As a Son in Duty bound,
Ten thouand times to peak I trove,
Ten thouand times truck dumb by Love.
Tranports of Wonder and Surprize
Raviht my Soul, and burt out of my Eyes:
But he preventing my Petition,
With a prophetical upicion,
Stroaking my Lethargick head,
In token of his Bleing, aid,
"Thy Vow is heard, and it is done,
"The Father's Merits for the Son,
"Make thee, thÃ´ an unworthy Heir,
"Fall to Praie, intead of Prayer.
"Go lay claim unto my Strains,
"My Mue inpire thy fruitful Brains,
"As a Reward for all thy pains.
"However, aim thou not too high;
"Some at their lowet higher flie,
"Than they that oar above the Skie;

"
Than they that oaring, never fell;
"Know your own phere, trive to excel
"In that to which your Genius leads.
"I never ung Heroick deeds,
"Nay, hould attempt it, all in vain,
"To write in Homer's lofty train:
"Yet in my own peculiar way
"Am every whit as fam'd as they.
"But one Rule more before we go:
"Let not your Fancy ebb and flow
"As your Brain on Spirits feeds,
"'T helps one Defect, and twenty breeds.
"Wine will nothing olid ettle;
"Hones by harpning, wear the Mettle.
"ThÃ´ the bewitching Cups of Liquor
"Made elevated thoughts the quicker,
"Yet the Grapetone top'd my breath,
"The Grape my life, the Grape my death.
This aid, Anacreon mil'd and neez'd,
A happy Omen he was pleas'd:
Then pull'd a Garland from his head,
(The Garland was of Myrtle made,
The Garland melt of Love and Wine,
With Violets, Palms, and Roes wrought,
And for a Song of Flora bought.
This he about my Temples twin'd,
And rapt in a trong blat of wind,
Left me and ordid Earth behind.
I for a Legacy did call,
He let his Book and Spaniel fall.
When out of ight the Coach was gone,
I put Anacreon's Garland on.
How glad I was to be undone!
The Philtre did effectual prove,
And nothing can thee Charms remove;
But I am plung'd in the Abys of endles Love.

div.head: Bion Idyl. 4.
< in non-Latin alphabet > , &c.
To Mrs. Mââââ Drââââr.
div.l: 'TIS the effect of Love, not ervile Fear,
The Mues fit their Songs to Cupid's Ear:
Proud at his feet to lay their Scepters down,
And pay Allegiance to their Soveraign's Crown.
'Tis only Love inpires Apollo's Lute,
Without that Harmony the Muick's Mute.
The Harp of Eloquence, Venus fairly won
At Pythian Games, a Preent for her Son.
Orpheus may tune up his Melodious Strings,
Yet none o weetly as the Siren ings.
For that Apotate (an eternal hame
Confound the Rebel, and his hateful Name!)
Whoe Actions all run counter to his Oath,
His debauch'd Judgment counter to them both;
Dull cribling Traytor, who would fain infue
Treaon into the heart of every Mue;
The wholome treams of our Parnaus mud
Wirh naty Dregs of Wine, and Lakes of Bloud;
With cold admittance thinks to baffle Love,
Blaphemouly the God a Batard prove;
Shall flagging flie, and in thoe flights till fall:
Parnaus Doves for him produce a Gall.
In vain he calls, and wells, and plits his Lungs,
Cupid has gagg'd their mouth, or ty'd their tongues;
But he that with His Inpiration ings,
Scorns the mean thredbare tile of warlike Kings,
Iambick Rage, great words, or mighty things:
But in a oft, a mooth, a gentle train,
Shall eae (and without pangs) his teeming Brain;
Shall as a Priet at Cupid's Altar wait,
And daily numerous Offerings conecrate.
His Reaon never in Eclipe decay,
Nor he want fire to animate his Clay.
Eteian Gales of Wit, Invention blow,
And Paion with Perfection joyntly flow.
Nature intent, whilt this her Mater ings,
And Immortality mount him on her Wings.
His Plaudits hall be eccho'd through the World,
Himelf to the Elyian Manions hurl'd.
By good Experience part my elf can prove,
I never write o well, as when I write of Love.

div.head: A Greek EPIGRAM to Hemiera. To Madam Aâ Râ.
div.l: WHen Pallas arm'd, met Venus in the Field,
Will you, aid he, the Prize of Beauty yield?
Venus reply'd, If naked with my Charms
I can prevail, what need have I of Arms?

div.head: The SNOW-BALL. A Tranlation. To Madam Dâ Bâ
div.l: I Dera Snow-balls made, and at me threw;
What can a perecuted Lover do?
What Labyrinths are thee in which I rove?
Inextricable are the Schools of Love.
Ev'n Snow, O Irony! to Fire he turns,
And every Vein, with cold truck thorough, burns.
Ah what o cold! yet that he could inpire,
With heat enough to kindle my deire,
Thrown only by her hands it et my heart on fire.
What Antidote can uch a Plague remove?
What place can ave me from the Charms of Love?
If ev'n the Elements uncontant prove;
If they (like all the World) begin to cheat,
If Contrarieties can o friendly meet,
And cold o naturally bring forth heat;
If Snow it elf a hidden Fire contains,
She only, only he can eae my pains;
She captiv'd firt my heart, he mut unlooe my Chains.
But ah! my flames cannot be quenched o,
By virtue of cold Ice, or frozen Snow.

div.head: To Idera wearing a MASK. A SONG To Madam Mâ Râ.

lg.l: WHY hould hoodwink'd Nature die?
And blinded Beauty fade?
Grace, Innocence, and Virtue lie
Smother'd in Maquerade?
Let Cupid's Monarchy diplay
His Flags of White and Red,
Nor give the World jut caue to ay,
Sick of a Maidenhead.
Why hould the Mountebanks lay claim
To th' Colours of your Skin?
'T may raie a candal on your Name,
ThÃ´ I hould think it in.
ThÃ´ my Implicit Faith be trong
Inviibles to believe,
ThÃ´ I hould think I did you wrong,
To ay you can deceive.
Dipel thoe happy Clouds that kis
Your Riing Sun uneen,
That trive to ravih all the Blis,
And interpoe a Screen.
Who would not at your Rays take fire?
T' Arabian Deerts flie,
And in a Spicy Nest expire,
And in a Fever die?
Pity a bleeding, wounded Hart,
Abandon'd by the Herd;
I'd die, but for my better part,
Life is to be preferr'd.
Let Venus boat her Mater-piece,
Let all the World admire;
Let me alone the Prize poes,
Troy, Greece,âmay be on fire.

div.head: Bion Idyl. 2.
< in non-Latin alphabet > , &c.
To Mr. Dryden.
div.l: A Little Stripling once a hooting went,
And hot he was, and on his Game intent:
He py'd the little blinking Buzzard, Love,
Sculking in a thick hady Myrtle Grove;
With joy and wonder truck, firt tones he flung,
And then his Bow, ure of his Buzzard, trung:
Cloe by the Tree, a Fated Arrow drew,
But Love too quick, till to another flew,
And all the Archer's Policy would not do.
Then to a good old Man he did himelf apply,
Told him the News, and hew'd Love perching up on high.
The Gaffer Plough-man miling, hook his head,
Pleas'd with the fancy, to the Artit aid,
Leave hooting, Youngster, and believe my words,
Thee are but feather'd Monters, Beats of Birds.
Were you at man's etate, he'd act your part;
Love's a damn'd Marks-man at a eaon'd heart.
ThÃ´ he flies now, then would he follow you,
And as a greedy Vultur cloe purue.
You are too young, he's for a noble Prey;
Yet let he take a liking to you, get you hence away.

div.head:
A PARAPHRASE On the twenty third Idyl. of Theocritus, From the beginning to
< in non-Latin alphabet > , &c.
To Idera.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: AN amorous little Swain
Was et to keep
His Father's goodly Flock of Sheep,
In the Arcadian Plain:
By chance a beauteous She came by,
Whom when his watchful Eyes did py,
His Guardian Eyes
That there tood Centinel, with wonder and urpize,
Marking the beauty of her Angel's face,
Set off with a weet Carriage, and a heavenly Grace,
Blet with a pleaant Mein, and prightly Air,
And all the dear Enchantments of the Fair;
Well atisfy'd, they let her pas:
Who thus admitted, did impart
The ecret to his wounded Heart.
Charm'd with the lovely Maid, that Fate had thither brought,
Whoe Beauty did urpas deire or thought;
In making whom,
Nature for once did thus preume
To go beyond her Rule, and place
On a weet Virgin's Body, a Cherub's Face;
Or rather to adorn
With more than heavenly Beauty, a Terretrial form.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: But ah! her Mind
Not like to her Seraphick Face, proud, cornful, and unkind;
Depiing thoe whom Paion,
Whom reitles Paion mov'd,
To humble Adoration,
Thoe who didain'd her mot, he above all things lov'd.
She knew not, nor deir'd to know
The fatal power of Cupid's Bow,
How oft, and how infallibly he throws
An amorous golden Dart,
To pierce the refractory Heart
That dare his injur'd Deity expoe;
Cruel in deed and word:
Ne're the leat hopes of comfort would dicover,
To a depairing, burning, dying Lover.
But in her Veins, Fury for Paion boils,
No roie Lips, no pleaant Smiles,
No bluhing Cheeks, no languihing Eyes,
That might eem to ympathize;
But as a chaed Boar that fills
With roaring all the neighbouring Hills,
With Vengeance cats his Eyes around,
And foaming, tears the groaning ground;
Till ditant Vales the Eccho trembling take;
The Foret all and every Creature hake:
So he, glances her Eyes upon the Swain,
With deperate Didain,
Adding more fewel to his never dying Pain.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: With corn her Countenance turn'd pale,
And all her other Charms began to fail;
Didain had banih'd every Grace,
Thoe blazing Comets of her Face,
Pride and Contempt took place.
Yet the Shepherd finds no Arms
For thee fainting, ickly Charms.
Her divine Sweetnes he mut till admire,
Struck blind from Heaven with Cupid's fire,
The flahes of an impotent deire.
Alas! how vain does peechles Reaon prove!
When enter'd in that Tyrant's Schools,
We learn his Epidemick Rules;
And fetter'd in the Chains of Love,
Turn Fahionable Fools:
We cannot call our elves our own,
But our affections pay obeyance to another's Crown.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: No longer able to contain,
ThÃ´ all in vain,
ThÃ´ all his words were Offerings to the Wind,
Deaf as he was unkind!
Tears like the Torrent of a welling Floud,
Tears from the Heart exhal'd, and drops of Bloud,
Their inking banks did overflow,
And drown the famih'd Vales below.
Trembling with dread and awful fear,
At lat he ventur'd to draw near
The Object of his Love, the Caue of his Depair.
Firt he preumes to kis
The acred ground whereon he with Devotion trod,
As in the preence of an angry God,
And then he trove to peak;
But concious Jealouie oft gave a check,
And made his half-out-liping words draw back.
Stam'ring at lat he forc'd out uch a Speech as this.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: "Inexorable, cruel, tony Saint!
"Blind to my Tears, and deaf to my Complaint!
"Sure of ome Liones, or Tyger born,
"Unworthy of my Love, as I unworthy of your Scorn!
"A grateful Preent to your Shrine I bring,
"The Welcome, and the only welcome thing,

"
That to my comfort, mut remain,
"To eae me of my Pain,
"To eae me of my Love, and you of your Didain;
"And Lo! proud haughty Nymph, and Lo!
"How willingly I go,
"How willingly I go, and take delight
"In your Commands, thÃ´ banih'd from your ight.
"I go where every Love-ick mind
"An univeral Remedy may find;
"The place is call'd Oblivion's Land,
"And Lethe's lazy Lake i'th' midt does tand;
"Which were it poible that I could dry,
"In flames unquenchable I till hould fry;
"Nor could I yet forget thy Name,
"So oft have I repeated o're the ame.
"But find alas! no Water that can quench my Flame.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: "Adieu, fair Virgin! and eternally adieu!
"Yet thou proud Anaxarete! learn what doom
"Undoubtedly hall on thy Beauty come,
"And from my dying mouth believe it true.
"The pleaant Day is quickly done,
"Flowers in the Morning freh, cut down by Noon;
"The bluhing Roes fade, and wither oon;
"White Snow that melts before the corching Sun,
"So youthful Beauty's full of Charms, all in a moment gone

"
The time will come, when you your elf will prove
"How great a Deity is Love,
"Beauty, or Wit, will ev'n that cornful Soul alarm,
"A wanton Ovid, or a fair Adonis Charm;
"You'll offer Hecatombs of Prayers,
"Bedew your Sacrifice with flouds of tears,
"Day and night igh would, but you dare not woo,
"For all's in vain that you can do,
"No greater pity will you find than I from you.
"Then will your tortur'd Concience bring me into mind,
"Not to encourage you, but erve you in your kind;
"My retles Ghost hall come,
"Not with oft Sighs, but Io's loud at your deerved doom.

lg.head: VII.
lg.l: "And yet grant me but this, ev'n this at leat,
"I'll ask no more, but grant me this Requet,
"Pull out the fatal Dagger from my Breat,
"And come and igh and mourn a while;
"I ask not (what I long'd for once) a Smile:
"But pull the Dagger from the Wound,
"And cloe, and cloe embrace me round:
"Thy Veil over my lifeles Body pread,
"Give me one kis, one kis when I am dead.
"I ask no more, coy Daphne! grant but this,
"A meeting, parting Kis,

"
Seal my cold Lips with thine,
"When thou hat uckt up all my dying breath,
"And mournful Cypres round my Temples twine,
"When to th' Elyian Manions I am fled.
"Nor needt thou fear, thus ummon'd after death,
"My raviht Sould hould come again;
"No, all thy Courthip is in vain,
"All cannot draw me from the Joys of the Elyian Plain.

lg.head: VIII.
lg.l: Then build me up a tately Tomb,
For a cloe Retiring Room;
In it place a Downy Bed,
Where Love may lay his worn Confederate's head;
And leave me, after thou hat three times aid,
My Duerates, He! Soul of my Soul, is dead.
Ah, cruel Death! that couldt us two divide,
Had Jove but pleas'd that I for thee had di'd!
Write this upon my Monument, to prove
Your own Unworthy Scorn, my Contant Love:
Here lies a Lover, Kill'd by deep Depair;
Stay Reader, tay,
And only be o kind to ay,
Alas! he lov'd, alas! he lov'd a Cruel Fair.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: FOrtune! thou lippery Stage of Kings,
Upon whoe Smiles or Frowns
Depends the Settlement or Fall of Crowns!
What various Chances treacherous Fortune brings,
Mounting on deceitful Wings!
To Monarchs Scepters gives, and ets them up on high
Upon the tottering Spires of Dignity;
Then leaves them all alone,
Hung in the Air, upon a Windy Throne,
Volatil Fortune mut be gone:
So let them fall or rie,
Away the bae perfidious Juggler flies.
How cant thou put a Cheat on us, o bare,
Give us but Tinel Goods for Solid Ware?
Wouldt have them rich and gay appear,
ThÃ´ truly little worth, and truly very dear.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: 'Tis not a Conqueror's Sword or Crown,
A Prince's Smile, or Tyrant's Frown,
Can make Cares at ditance keep,
Or buy one hort-liv'd moment's leep.
Greatnes is nothing but a pleaant Fable,
Nor can it make a Soul invulnerable.
The Court is no ecurity from pains,
Princes have wore their Chains.
One Miery on another's neck does ride;
'Tis a troubled Sea, when Fortune is our Guide;
And 'tis a rare unuual ight,
In Fate's black Webs to ee one thread of white.
The raging Waves tear up the Sand,
And foaming beat againt the Land;
Yet not o fat the Tyde can flow,
Yet not o fat the Wind can blow,
As giddy Fortune rahly throw
Out of her careles hand, the doubtful Die,
When in the twinkling of an Eye,
Kings Beggars, Beggars Kings, turn'd at her Lottery.
Kings would be fear'd, but even Kings we ee,
Fear, let they that fear them, hould ue Treachery.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: 'Tis not the Night can give the Balm of Rest
To thoe whoe Spirits are oppret
With Care, that Night-Mare on their breat.
Sleep is no Antidote t' expel
Fear, that Firebrand of Hell.
What City will not impious Arms detroy?
Slight was the Caue, great was the Fall of Troy.
Bloud-thirty War wallows whole Kingdoms down,
Nor makes two mouthfuls of a Crown.
See the vat Pyramids that once ev'n reach'd the Skie,
Like Mole-hills in the dut, or Atoms lie.
Chatity is at Court a hateful name,
And ilenc'd Jutice put to hame:
They laugh at Wedlock's Sacred Tye,
Stifle gaping Innocence,
Perjure their Reaon, and debauch their Sence,
And impudently give ev'n Truth it elf the Lye.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: But War in Hotile manner tands
With Spear advanc'd, and bloudy hands:
And there Jove's Executioners all wait
To overturn thoe Pinacles of State.
Furies in the Triumphant Chariot ride,
With Whips to check the Conul's pride.
Death in a thouand dreadful hapes appears,
And gnaws on Concience prepoet with fears.
Crowns from weight, and care from Kings,
Are both ineparable things.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: Yet uppoe Fate offers no Violence,
Publick Peace, private Innocence,
Still things that are o high and great,
Cannot upport their feeble height,
But tottering down, ink under their own weight.
If Sails be fill'd, thÃ´ by a properous wind,
Thoe Gales may prove unkind.
A Whirlwind overturns the Tower that hrouds
Its lofty top amongt the Clouds.
The little Shrubs in humble hades that pread,
See the vat Oak, whoe proud apiring head
Defied the Thunderer, in the Forret lie
Saples, wither'd, crackt, and drie.
Flahes of Lightning only Mountains trike;
In this alone are Fortune's Scales alike:
Whatever's above weight mut over fall,
Without exception, All.
Great Bodies, too luxurious grown
With omething more than properly their own,
Predominant Dieaes feed
Corruption in the Bloud, and Humours breed.
The fattet Cattel are for laughter choe,
To dangers Greatnes mut expoe.
Whatever tottering Fortune does exalt,
Has only Crutches lent to learn to halt.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: Low moderate things mut needs bear longet date,
That man is truly, and is only Great,
That lives contented with a mean Etate.
Thrice happy is that man whoe Means do lie
Above, or ele below curt Fortune's Eye;
Nor like a Coward to the hore does creep,
Nor rahly thruts himelf into the deep,

div.head: Parting with His Dear Brother, Mr. Ah Wyndham.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: MAke room, ye Pygmie Sons of Fame,
That with Antiquity would well your name,
Proud before others, to have trod
The Paths of Virtue, and the Ways of God.
ThÃ´ lat, I'll mend my pace,
Not they that et out firt, mut win the Race.
'Tis done! and now, methinks,
The tately Monument of Nius inks,
And all thoe Hero's dut to nothing hrinks.
'Tis done! I mount upon the Wings of Love,
And through the Sky, by the Twin-Stars I move;
From whence thoe little Atoms I review,
That once with Titles fill'd the World,
Thouands into a crowded Pitcher hurl'd,
Wet with the Tears of Moiture and of Dew.
'Tis done! and all the Field's my own,
But till what hall I do to be for ever known?
How hall I keep up this my flight,
And prove 'tis not Preumption, but my Right?
'Tis done! and the unquetionable Heir,
Dear Corydon, will to my Title wear,
Ev'n He, whoe name had pread from Pole to Pole,
Great and diffuive as his Soul:
Had Fame, with all her hundred Tongues, but breath
To ound him loud enough, till after death,
Whoe Name was made to comprehend
All the Virtues of a Friend:
Too great for words, whoe Soul needs no tranlation, Nature's one only work of Supererogation.
Oh! I could almot with that Fate would try
How unconcern'd for thee I durt to die;
How at the fatal Altar I could mile,
Griev'd only at thy abence for a while.
Proud as a Harbinger, to go before
To chue ome melancholy Grove,
Where I together with my thoughts might rove,
And thy aupicious Name implore.
Yet if not entenc'd to depart,
How gladly could I watch the Guardian of my heart!
Nor yet by day, nor yet by night,
Let thee teal one hort moment from my ight.
How with thy abence can I be content,
When every minute without thee, is mi-pent?
But ah! the Fruit's forbidden for a time,
And who the Tree dares climb?
Now were not Jealouie a in,
I could once more, once, and eternally begin
Thy Faith, thy Promie to ecure,
Not in a thouand Oaths ecure.
Pardon (Dear Corydon!) too zealous Love,
That fain would all things prove;
Afraid on lender grounds to trut,
Or can a Friend be over jut?
For thÃ´ my faultring fears betray
Supicious doubts, yet I mut till believe
'T's impoible for Corydon to deceive;
Whoe heart's Truth's Hieroglyphick well expret,
Preiding in the Temple of your Breat.
Where on that Altar I mut humbly lay
This Offering, with my conecrated Vow,
My Sibyl's Golden Bough.
I wear by your own elf, and truth by you,
That to the elf-ame Oath I will be true:
Nor need I tell you, for you needs mut know,
I love you above all things here below.
By Heaven once more, and the Almighty Powers,
Intirely and eternally I'm Yours,

div.head: To Mr. G. L. an ODE.

lg.l: DEar George, the better part
Of my united, now divided heart,
Accept of thee rude Lines this Paper bears,
Conceiv'd in Sorrow, and brought forth in Tears;
Sad as th' Occaion, haty as thy Flight:
Nor wonder, if with o much pains
They wrought their paage through my brains:
No wonder, if o hardly I the Dirge endite,
Which ev'n my Pen clog'd with grief, cannot write:
No wonder, if my Veres lag behind,
Since my Mue with Tears is blind,
I to this Prion here confin'd;
For ure no better is that place to me,
Whilt thou are abent, whereoe're it be.
Seven days are pat, ince I beheld thy face,
In which Divinity it elf is writ,
And Angel all in every line of it;
Picture of Beauty, and the Stamp of Grace.
Seven! to what immene number does that word amount!
Seven days! 7000 years in Love's account.
Every Minute is a Day,
Every Hour a tedious Year,
In which the Sun does once appear,
And in a moment vanihes away,
And leaves the mierable cloudy Hemiphere.
Seven days! before I could my ilence break,
Thy Name in Accents interrupted peak.
For even long days upon the Rack,
And overwhelmed with the dreadful torm,
Grief haunted me like th'evil Spirit of Saul;
Then in my wavering mind I thought,
What if I hould my elf to David's Harp apply?
And might not numbers be a Remedy?
I tried and found it nonence all;
I tried again, and at the econd draught,
Like old Deucalion's Stones, all came to better form.
To ay, my Life is bound in thine,
In deed were a Tautologie;
For that as necearily mut be,
As that thou hat a Soul divine.
But to expres the Grief and Conternation,
When Soul and Body part;
For uch it is does eize my heart,
That, that only is above my paion.
Each day, my Sun, ince you withdrew your light,
Has been an everlating Night;
And yet till banih'd, Thyris, from thy ight!
I feel the Pangs and Tortures of a dying Soul;
Nay, I my elf am dead, thÃ´ but in part,
Whilt you are my Vicegerent in my heart,
And mut command the whole.
'Tis this alone that does upport
My inking Spirits from the Grave,
That thÃ´ the Scorpion tings, her bloud can ave.
Greatnes and Fortune do your abence court;
ThÃ´ Fate does her malicious Nature how,
To make uch bitter treams from a weet Fountain flow.
Methinks I Pylades and Oretes ee,
And mut admire their contancie;
But when again I do recount
To what vat um my Debts amount,
How infinitely I am oblig'd to thee,
Their Friendhip in the Balance laid,
And equally and fairly weigh'd
Againt my potles Love,
Lighter than Vanity does prove,
Tilts up, (like Vapours that the Air invade)
Whilt mine is olid and does downward to its centre move:
No more to be compar'd, than Atoms to the Sun,
Or little drops unto the boundles Ocean.
Pylades proffer'd his own Life, ('tis true)
And bare that punihment was jutly due
To Oretes, who kill'd his Mother. uch a Friend; but hadtPylades. thou died
Intead of him, thou hadt been til'd the Matricide,

This, according to Tully's Maxim in his Treatie De AmicitiÃ¢, proves, that thee two could not be true Friends; for, ays he, Amicitia nii in bonis ee non potet. Quid igitur? an caedes, bonum? His horrid Crime transferr'd to you:
That Murther oon have put an end
To that proverbial name of Friend.
But as thy matchles Innocence
<note n="" place="bottom">An Apotrophie to his Friend. Could only be a capital Offence,
Thy Vertues I would ranom by my death,
And bles the Author with my dying breath.
This I with les reluctancy could bear,
Than uch damnation to depair,
Than abence from that glorious Sun,
Who lends all Creatures light, and yet himelf wants none.
'Tis from his Rays I teal Promethean fire,
Kindle my fatalAn Alluion to the Phoenix. Spices, and expire:
Whoe Worth and Vertues when I think upon,
Tot by two different motions of my mind,
But both to the ame end inclin'd,
I cannot be with-held, I mut be gone:
My Soul is on the wing;
But being topt by cros Neceity,
She makes a Pot of every Wind,
Sends word he fears you grow unkind;
Commits to every blat a igh,
Then melts away into a piece of Poetry.
So when the Nightingale has gor'd her breat,
She tunes her Pipes, and quavers out her bet:
And thÃ´ in the extremity of pain,
Has not forgot her uual train,
But ets her elf to ing.

div.head: The SPRING. To Mr. Ben. Wrighton.

q.l: Ver adeÃ² frondi nemorum, ver utile ylvis:
Vere tument terrae, & genitalia emina pocunt.

div.l: HAil fragrant Spring! the charming pride of May,
Let Heaven mile upon this olemn day,
The Sun new dret, hine with a brighter ray.
The Feverih Summer, Aguih Winter flie,
Conumptive Autumn with her Palie die,
Or banih'd hence at the dread Queen's command,
Go take poeion in another Land.
For Flora comes with Royal Garlands crown'd,
The Flowers kis her feet upon the ground;
The Mues, Graces, and good Genius dance,
And with jut Meaures and weet Tunes advance.
Birds winged Sirens, Choriters of the Sky,
In Conort ing, and in Proceion fly;
Each keeps his proper Time, and Note, and Place,
Whilt falling murmuring Rivers ing the Bae.
The Eatern winds Arabian Odours breath,
The Wetern upwards blow thoe Sweets they uck'd beneath.
The Fields array'd in their new Robes of State,
Upon their bounteous Benefactor wait.
Birds fan their wings, & pread their peckled plumes,
And Violets make a Preent of Perfumes.
The Air on Primroes and Lillies feeds,
Melts Spices, and prolifick moiture breeds.
The Woodbinds and the Honyuckles trive
Which with Ambroia firt can tock a Hive.
Nature does entertain the Queen with Feats,
And Plays and Masks acted by wanton Beats:
The Elephant plays Gambols with his Trunk;
The Grahopper with dew of Nectar drunk,
To his own Muick leads a Country-Dance:
Mettleom Hores, through their Pature prance;
The active Roes and Kids at Leap-Frog play;
The whole Creation keeps a Holy day.
Now tempting Venus, naked in her Hair,
With her Gallants walks out to take the Air.
Love in his Mother's Locks hides all his Darts,
And takes his rounds to ingle out his Hearts:
And here and there, till as he paes by,
At random lets an amorous Arrow fly.
Day and night Vulcan his vat Bellows blows,
Day and night the Cyclopian Anvil glows
With harden'd Metal work'd on th' Forge of Fate,
For Shafts, ome gilt with Love, ome tipp'd with Hate.
His Stock for all the following year, new ground,
Poion'd to carry Death in every Wound.
Proud Peacocks with their Tails expanded trut,
And jealous Rams for recreation butt.
The Warlike Steed waves up and down his Main,
The Warlike Steed, the Champion of the Plain.
The Bull fights bloudy Duels for his Mate,
And to keep up the Grandeur of his State.
No Fleecy Tempets gather in the Sky,
Nor raging Dog-tars torrid heat now fry.
But Sol with his new Chariot hines more bright,
His Hores breath les flame, and clearer light.
The Silver Streams double refined flow,
And Fihes frisk, to ee the pompous Show.
Home the kind Oak the Vine his Wife receives,
And hides her nakednes with his own Leaves.
Turtles together billing it, and coo,
And with alternate glances ilent woo.
Nightingales charm the litning Woods, to wret
Their tender Sprigs, to make a downy Net.
Flora's conducted to her Vernal Throne,
And now a Trumpet for Retreat is blown.
Once more her Court, the painted Gardens mile,
And weat out moiture from their fruitful Soil.
The ickly Plants revive, look freh and fair,
The Seaon temperate, clear the Morning Air:
The Evening drops down various weets in howers;
Proerpine plunders Sicily for Flowers.
The little eager Virgin never tands,
But fills her Lap, her Boom, and her Hands:
The Blooms, pret by an untimely death,
Spin out their Odour with their dying breath:
(As Bees, kill'd by the wanton Boys in play,
Their Honey from their welling Bags convey.)
Blind Pluto comes, innocent his deign!
Led by the cent, and lights on Proerpine:
Then greedy to ecure thoe fragrant Sweets,
He takes her too, and rifles all he meets.
Now more than her Elyian Joys invite,
Now Fate unlocks the Iron Gate of Night,
The Prioner viits Ceres and the Light.
Almighty Jupiter decends to lie
With Mother Earth, and paing through the Skie,
The corching heat of Signs malignant damps,
And with freh Oyl upplies the heavenly Lamps.
Now Mother Earth's full time is almot come,
Parent of all things, bears a pregnant Womb.
Nature is hatching Plenty on her Net,
Nature by youthful Saturn firt compret.
This is the Life and Spirit of the Year,
With a brisk Air thus Janus does appear.
This the lick skin, the hrivel'd Snake does wear,
when her old cae is ragged, looe, and bare.
Harmonious Muick, and Seraphick Love,
Is all thoe happy Souls enjoy above.
Now Earth is like the Manions of the Blet;
Muick in every Grove, and Love in every Breat.
Here in this natural Landskip we may ee
Heperian Paradie in Epitomie:
For what was Paradie, but eternal Spring?
Let Birds of Paradie its Praies ing.
Hail, Sacred Spring! Hail to thy lovely Green!
Let the World hout, Amen; and cry, God bles the Queen.

q.l: Non alios primÃ¢ crecentis origine Mundi
Illuxie Dies, aliumve habuie tenorem
Crediderim. Ver illud erat: ver magnus agebat
Orbis, &c.

div.head: Learning.
div.l: WHen dimal Chaos did the World confound,
And all lay in a common Deluge drown'd,
Horror, Depair, and Death reign'd all around.
Parnaus was the lat that diappear'd,
Or firt his reverend top apiring rear'd.
The Olive-Tree then lifted up her head,
And mil'd to ee no Rival Beauty bred.
Thus Learning is the next to our Salvation;
Lat of the old, or firt o'th' new Creation.

div.head: To Mr. R. Smith of King's Colledge in Cambridge.

q.l: Ingentes animos anguto in Corpore verant.

div.l: I Hear, my Friend, ome dare profane your name,
Derogate from your Merit and your Fame,
Preume your Body, for a capacious Mind
Too little, as if Dwarfs were Fools by kind.

l.U: ure was no uch bouncing Dame,

div.l: The puny Product of Jove's little Brain.
Apollo too was but a Dapper Twin,
By Nature and by Birth the next akin:
Apollo all the Wit from Dian tole,
Shar'd half his Father's Rape, but all his Soul.
The other rough, unhewen, long Lubbers made,
For Nonence, Service, Slavery, and Trade.
The Sacred Laurel is it elf but low,
And with its humble and ubmiive bough,
Does court the mighty Brain, the little Brow.
What thÃ´ your Body be diminutive,
Heav'n to your Soul can no addition give.
Inects that have mot Legs, do lowet crawl;
The Dove of all Birds, only wants a Gall.
What greater Bruits go by the name of men,
Than a Therites, or a Saracen?
What thÃ´ dumb Animals we can depie,
The wiest man yet thought the Ant was wie.
A Nut-hell held the worth of Homer's Brain,
And a mall Bottle could the Winds contain.
From narrow Streights vat rapid Billows flow,
And Zephyrus fruitful Gales do gently blow.
Full as much Prudence to the Bee is given,
As any wing'd Inhabitant of Heaven.
And the leat Body jutly may apire
To one mall park of the Celetial Fire,
The Great can do no more, the Great can mount no higher.
The barren Tree can in the Dearts pread,
And threaten Heaven with its luxurious head:
Whilt others low, and laden with their Fruit,
With bended Branches touch their very root.
Let Fools and Coxcombs prate what they think fit,
And burt with Envy, they mut till ubmit
To Pygmie Members, and Gigantick Wit.

div.head: To Idera in Mourning, Going into Mourning Himelf oon after.

lg.l: PRovident Fate conider'd well,
When at one double troke two fell,
For both to toll one Paing-bell.
Not that his tock of Shafts was low,
Nor did they one another know
For Fellow-Travellers below.
But when he aw one bleeding heart,
In different Liveries forc'd to part,
She drew a reconciling Dart.
When therefore there a Blank was put,
Here Fate a Thread, grown rotten, cut,
And Eyes that could not open, hut.
Of hoary Grief now both partake,
Or ele a olemn Mourning make,
Idera! for one another's ake.
For thus by Heaven it was decreed,
Our Myrtle, for our Mourning Weed,
Our Streams from the ame Fountain flow;
From the ame Stalk our Troubles grow;
The Rie, the Root we only know.
So when one Flower's torn, and pret,
And mother'd in a teaming Breat,
That Wound will murther all the ret.
So if one Bae be truck alone,
The next that bears a heavy tone,
Will fetch a Sympathetick Groan.
Learn from your everlating Dye,
Not with your Black to change your Contancy,
'T were better you hould mourn alone, than I.

div.head: A Paradox in Praie of Ambition.
To his dear Friend Mr. Edw. Taylour, of Merton Colledge in Oxford.

q.l: âDeus immortalis haberi
Dum cupit Empedocles, ardentem fervidus Aetnam
Iniluit.

lg.l: SOul of the World! Spark of Promethean Fire!
Sick of this lower Orb, my Breat inpire!
Mount me upon thy Wings!
To blow thy Thundring Trumpet Fame,
To be the Herald of thy Name,
And tune thy peaking Strings!
Let me for ever at thy Altars wait,
Know what it is to be divinely Great.
Thou art the whole Creation's Mytick Sun,
And thou art all its Beauties drawn in one!
For when thy Glory's et,
Thick Clouds mut intercept the Light,
Black Darknes, and eternal Night
Their old Dominion get,
When thou art banih'd from thy Royal Throne,
Confuion mut her Firt-born Chaos own.
Thou dot our groveling Souls from Earth tranport,
From ordid Earth, with Jove to keep our Court:
Thou dot of God partake
A Particle of heavenly Air,
The Badge of Honour that we wear
For our Ditinction ake:
Ele Bruits might claim preeminence over Man,
Nay Bruits would uffer by th' Comparion.
Thy Engine mounts our noble thoughts on high,
Deucalion's Stones have learnt the art to flie:
Thou dot our Metal prove,
Thou hat the everlating Springs
On which all great and mighty things
In their right order move;
Thy Spirit does life unto our Souls dipence,
Thy Center's every-where, but no-where thy Circumference.
Nor can our leaden Faculties apire
To one great Action, till thy Vetal Fire
On our blind Reaons hine;
From Sleep our dull Affections raie,
Free Paions from a mity maze,
Our droie part refine.
Whatever's wonderful, from thee mut come,
Mut be conceiv'd in thy Omnicient Womb.
What is it that I hear Caear thy Heir,
Caear, Soul of thy Soul, devoutly wear,
This Light hall either ee
Caear degraded to a Tomb,
Or Caear Pontifex of Rome,
A Slave, or Monarch He.
Here Soveraign Prince, or there a Soveraign Shade,
Where amongt Nothings, no Ditinction's made.
It was a thought worthy of thy own Spirit,
Nor was Rome over anwerable for his Merit.
She could not put him by,
For over-rul'd by Power Divine,
They all their Hearts and Voices joyn,
And Caear, Caear cry.
It was the breathing of a Soul inpir'd,
With a true Principle of Honour fir'd.
Thus Calchas baffled in Prophetick trife,
Redeem'd his Honour by his los of life.
And thus in Robes of State,
When ranack'd Rome was all on fire,
The Senate only did deire,
Like Gods, to meet their Fate.
Thus Hannibal could Death it elf command,
Reolv'd to fall by none but his own hand.
Stoicks in vain a Rigorous Life defend,
And to renounce all Paions would pretend:
Whilt they ubmit to thine,
Thee Soveraign over Nature own,
As a jut Tribute to thy Throne,
Bodies and Souls reign.
See Cato, for his Honour bleeding lie,
Brutus, the Bet of men, for Glory die.
Of Alexander, what hould I reheare?
Who took a Journy through the Univere,
Did all things there ubdue;
Kingdoms againt Kingdoms hurl'd,
At one troak conquer'd all the World,
And hock'd ev'n Nature too:
At lat with Tears cram'd into a mall Tomb,
Complaining in thee narrow treights for want of room.
And now methinks ten thouand Heroes throng,
To hear and bear a part in this my Song;
Where in the Front I py
Hercules by his Pillars tand;
Scaevola with his wither'd hand;
Codrus and Decius vy:
With Palms the Royal Champions all in white
In a Proceion go, a Glorious Sight!
What thÃ´ th' Rebellious Giants groaning lie,
Stretcht out under a vat Eternity?
What thÃ´ that hateful name
Catiline greedy to be Great,
Make nothing to devour a State?
Their's was a Batard Flame.
For pure Ambition nothing will ugget,
Nothing but what will tand ev'n Virtue's Tet:
Nor a dihonourable Scaffold climb,
To build to Heaven, to compas her deign;
Nor when in quet of Fame,
To quench her never-dying Thirt,
Take draughts of Poion till he burt,
And o procure a Name.
From a bae Thought or Action he will fly,
Too near akin to Virtue to comply.
When Heav'n firt made our active Souls of Fire,
Heaven deign'd thoe flames hould all apire.
Can we be o unjut,
Our divine Natures to debae?
Crawl with the Serpent on our Face,
And lick our Native Dut?
Our Souls as heavy as our Corps of Clay,
Not unlike Worms, were we not wore than they.
But above all our Tribe with thee poet,
Indulge thy brooding motions in their breat.
In thy wing'd Chariot rie,
The glorious works of God urvey,
The Regions of eternal Day,
And Flowery Paradie:
Sometimes above take an immortal flight,
Or pas through Tempe's Valleys of Delight.
Thou with the influence of thy fruitful Beams
Reflect't a warmth on Helicon's cold treams:
By thee, the heavenly Quire
All their harmonious Anthems ing,
Apollo without thee's no King,
Thou breathet on his Lyre.
By thee the Palm pret down, till higher hoots,
Till Heaven her Branches kis, and Hell her roots.
Full of thy Power I can no more contain,
But the exces of Pleaure turns to pain;
Alas what hall I do?
Still but a younger Son of Fame,
Nor thatâa Cypher of a Name,
A Dwarfih Poet too?
How hall I Nature underhand engage,
Not thus to meaure out my Portion by my Age?
What Manure is't will ripen Barren Brains?
How hall I pin out Sene in Waller's trains?
Oh! that I could but draw
All thoe beauteous Charms that lie
Under the Veil of Poetrie,
And could train Nature's Law,
To comprehend all Widom, and all Wit,
Nor, by thy light, upon the Rocks of Error plit!
What hall I do to be for ever known,
And make Perfection's Quinteence my own!
But all my thought's in vain,
I only can my elf apply
To Caear's fatal Remedy,
I flag in every train,
And like the Nightingale mut e'en expire,
Vanquih'd, and dumb on the Victorious Lyre.

div.head: To Idera. Age in a Looking-glas.

q.l: O quam continuis, & quantis longa enectus
Plena malis! deformem, & tetrum ante omnia vultum,
Diimilemque ui, deformem pro cute pellem,
Pendenteque genas, & tales adpice jugas,
Quales umbriferos ubi pandit Tabraca altus,
In vetulÃ¢ calpit jÃ m mater imia buccÃ¢, &c.
Juv. Sat. 10.

div.l: DO not, haughty Nymph, didain
The Incene of an Humble Swain!
What thÃ´ you're Great? what thÃ´ you're Fair?
Age and Death will not pare.
A furrow'd Cheek, a wrinkled Chin,
An old tough Hide, a Saffron Skin,
Sore, Rheumy Eyes, the Senes gone,
Fal'n Jaws, nothing but skin and bone,
The Picture of a Skeleton,
May be thought omething like a Face,
To one that loves the former Grace;
The like Marpea chue a Joy,
Not tranient, nor apt to cloy:
A contant Love, that's like to lat,
ThÃ´ Clouds and Storms hould overcast.
Apollo takes you for a time,
And only courts to tate your Prime:
A God too goodly to engage
His Faith to Females for an Age:
Mut through all Cupid's Labyrinths range,
His Love as often as his Viage change;
But Idas, thÃ´ a Mortal, yet may prove
Immortal in his Love:
None can like Idas contant be,
And none like Idas can reemble Me.

div.head: SOLITDE. To his dear Brother, Mr. Ah Wyndham.

q.l: Sic ego ecretis poum bene vivere ylvis,
Qua nulla humano it via trita pede.
Tu mihi curarum requies, tu nocte vel atrÃ¢
Lumen, & in olis tu mihi Turba locis.

lg.l: O Corydon! how I hug my elf to think!
When in this troubled Sea the World,
All thrut into the Main,
Till by a Hurricane,
Through the Abys with Vengeance hurl'd,
With horrible Adieus they parting ink.
Whilt I upon the ilent hore, ecure,
Fear neither tormy Wind nor Tide,
With elevated Soul,
Can move from Pole to Pole,
And through the aery Regions glide,
Need only pity what they mut endure.
The World will take no notice of my Name;
Well then I'll let th' Impotor ee
I have my Paions broke,
Brought Pride to wear a Yoke,
I'm as Indifferent as he;
NoâI will never top her Trump of Fame.
That cured word the World bliters my Tongue,
It breaths out all the Plagues of Hell;
'Tis Nonence intricate,
Unintelligible tate,
That puzzles all my Brains to pell,
If I gues right, Man's Dust the World is Dung.
I never could any Contexture find,
Confuion only is her coure,
Her Joys but pleaant Fictions,
A Mas of Contradictions,
All Guilt, all Trouble and Remore;
This is the World, or he or I am blind.
She never yet was in true Colours drawn;
All, Diappointments, Pains, and Fears,
One Scene of Miery,
Contant Incontancy,
Tempetuous World, a Vale of Tears,
For our chief Happines Chance the only Pawn.
Paions, and Dicontents, and Jealouies,
Publick War, and Dometick Strife,
Perjury and Deceit,
This Gall confounds the Sweet,
And poions all the Joys of Life;
And our vains Hopes mut end in penitential Sighs.
Oh! I am ick, and my head giddy turns,
The thoughts of noie I cannot bear,
Buines that kills me too,
Death is les terrible than Care;
To get from this Fools Paradie my heart burns.
Who would not then with us, dear Friend, retire?
Accept the happines to hroud
Under a hady Screen,
To walk along uneen,
Wrapt like Aeneas in a Cloud,
And ee the World, as he did Troy, on fire.
'Tis more than time, my Soul, that we were gone,
Delay, my Corydon, does us wrong;
The World will grow more bold,
Still loth to quit her hold,
For her Temptations they are trong.
Come then and put blind Pluto's Helmet on.
âWhat a fair propect now have we!
Can unditurb'd together tand,
Enjoy our elves, and all
The World her goods can call,
And touch the Globe but with our hand,
And all things pat, preent, and future ee.
Here at Earth's puff'd up Bubbles we can mile,
Her fucus'd Vanities depie,
Divert with pleaant Chat,
Dicoure of this or that,
Still aiming to be truly wie,
With Books, or harmles port, the time beguile.
Full of our elves, what can we wih for more?
We find us work enough, to tend
The habit of our Soul,
Our Paions to controul,
To do the Duties of a Friend,
'Tis the mitaken World, not we, are poor.
Here in an empty Theater we it,
Retir'd to keep our Holy-day,
Our Minds the Scenes mut be,
The Critical Spectators we,
Of one anothers Life, the Play,
The Authors and the Judges of our Wit.
If we have acted well in Heaven's ight,
What thÃ´ we hear no ecchoing Stage?
Or when our State we change,
What thÃ´ our names eem trange,
Unknown to a ucceeding Age?
Without that Witnes happy Democrite!
Why hould we Fame, that treacherous Idol, court?
That ets us up for Envy's Mark,
That burns us with the Rays
Of undeerved Praie,
Only to blind us in the dark,
To throw us down again, for fear or port.
Fame's breath is hort, when he must trumpet loud:
'Tis eldom that he comes alone;
She's an uncontant Guet,
That loves to change her Net,
True Worth, true Praie would not be known.
The Sun looks brightet through a ilver Cloud.
On an embroider'd Bank here we can pick and chue
An unbought, avory, wholome Dih,
On Leaves erve up our Fare,
Perfum'd with the weet Air:
Then Corydon! to compleat our Wih,
Our Recreation, Friendhip, and a Mue.
Sometimes we take a pride to tand and ee
Bees bring their yellow Harvet home,
Unload their welling Thighs,
And as their Goddes wie,
Spin it into their Hony-comb.
Happy Spectators! happy Rivals we!
Sometimes upon a Downy Couch of Gras,
On Flowery Cuhions tretcht we lie,
To hear a dying Swan,
More enible than Man,
Warble forth a weet Elegy:
Or in oft Tunes the purling Rivers pas.
Or ele diolv'd in Eae, lay down our heads
In Slumbers as our Natures kind,
Bound in each others Arms
By Virtue's trictet Charms,
Lull'd aleep by the whitling Wind,
On eaie Velvet, fragrant Violet-beds.
The name Diogenes jutly none can give,
Nor churlih call our Innocence:
With Solitude thus crown'd,
What Firebrand can be found?
Unles our Happines give offence:
For in the World, as out of it, we live.
Sometimes hear Eccho her Misfortunes tell,
See how he'll watch the lovly Boy
Narcius, as he looks
Into the Crytal Brooks:
Her vocal Reparties enjoy;
Or the melodious Notes of Philomel.
Sometimes in hady Groves together walk,
And atisfy'd with humble Sights,
See Art and Nature both diget
In Milton, Waller, and the ret:
Full and unparallel'd Delights!
Of Love and Solitude divinely talk.
Each Dryad that is worthy of the Wound,
Each Tree that's worthy of the Mark,
Our mutual Friendhip know,
Under our Aupice grow,
Thyris and Corydon on the Bark,
Thyris and Corydon the Woods reound.
But above all, the Ah apiring hoots,
Thy Badge of Honour proud to wear;
The Ah, a Tree for Jove,
The Ah, it elf a Grove,
Proud thy Name in hers to bear,
She nods her trembling Head, and trouts her welling Roots.
The Nymphs here take their rounds, and dance, and play;
The Hamadryads at us peep;
Crocus and Hyacinth, ome bring,
Daiies, the Maidenhead of the Spring:
Others behind us oftly creep,
And teal our Songs and Patorals away.
When our light hearts are for a looer Rein,
To Banquets we our elves invite,
Conorts of Muick and of Love,
Ambroia from above;
Veres for econd Coure recite,
And with alternate Trifles entertain.
Or we convere with Garden Myteries,
See the emulous Roes blat;
The loving Ivy twine;
The Wall cling to the Vine;
And Flora taking her repat:
Adam might envy in his Paradie.
And thus withdrawn from buines, noie, and trife,
We double our few fleeting days,
And when together fled,
Fate having cut our Thread,
Were we ent back into this Maze,
We'd act but the ame Scene, our former life.

q.l: Rura mihi & rigui placeant in vallibus amnes;
Flumina amem, ilvaque inglorius. O, ubi campi,
SperchiÃºque, & virginibus bacchata Lacaenis
Taygeta! O, qui me gelidis in vallibus Haemi
Sitat, & ingenti ramorum protegat umbra! &c.
Fortunatus & ille, deos qui novit agretes,

Pana
que Silvanum
que enem, Nymphaque orores.

div.head: To a young Lady that contantly lept at Church.

lg.l: I Often wonder'd, as I lay,
Wihing for my Books, and Day,
What Hag hould it upon my Breast,
That I could neither peak nor rest;
What could that Stranger Morpheus keep
From his nightly Tribute, Sleep.
When Love, with an enchanted Key,
Thus unlock'd the Mytery:
The Charms of Idera's piercing Eyes;
Then paid a Viit to her Heart,
And now he knows not how to part.
But here poet with Jealouie,
Himelf the Watch of her fair Eye,
Let with Religion tempting Jove
Should anticipate her Love,
From her Devotion in the day,
Reolves to ravih her away.
Will eize on Thyri's heart no more,
Stand Centry only at her door:
Nor will open Caements trut,
(Supicious are the Rapes of Lust)
But in her Bath a weating lies,
I'th' Exhalations of her Eyes.
Yet if 't be he does teal my leep,
If he my Senes waking keep,
Let thoe tolen Goods be weet,
Prop'rous the Pillage of her Sheet.
Till with thee he hares my Dreams.

l.U: till be happy, till be proud,

lg.l: To bear the Office of a Cloud:
For if her Sun thus raging burns,
Unles thy Fan the corching Fervour turns:
My Nest will e'en be et on fire,
And then the Phoenix mut expire.

div.head: To Idera, Putting a Copy of Veres in at her Window at Midnight.

q.l: Nox erat & Coelo fulgebat Luna ereno,
Inter minora yderaâ

div.l: THou concious Night, my Strategem conceal!
May no perfidious Dreams my Theft reveal!
No Tell-tale Stars come prying near this way,

l.U: ilent igns, dumb motions to betray!

div.l: Propitious Venus, only he hine bright!
To blind the ret, and give a Lover light!
Go to the Enemies Quarters, happy Scout!
"There unconcern'd, undaunted look about,
"Soft as thy Meage, as thy Mater tout.
"If any rude, uncivil Hand hould pres,
"Exclaim againt thy own unhappines!
"Or ilent trut th' event; Thou liely fraught
"With Sinon's Art, wilt to the Queen be brought:
"And when into her preence thou art come,
"She'll read a line or two, then ee from whom;
"Enquire where taken: till her heart will fail,
"The treacherous Prioner must be ent to Jayl,
"That comes to teal the Hotage of her Heart,
"And lies in Ambuh with the charming Art.

"
Idera mov'd with pity, will repent,
"Some pretty amorous punihment invent;
"Perhaps, as much as he has read, he'll burn,
"'Till Flouds of Tears the Flames hall inward turn;
"Sympathy only will the Fire remove,
"In the old Channel et the coure of Love.
"Under her Pillow the Remains he'll lay,
"By night to be her Dream, her Song by day.
"Which whilt he quavers out, the other part
"May pas her Guards, and eize her captiv'd Heart.
"Thou in Perfumes halt either raviht die,
"Or in the Milky Way tranlated lie.
"Go my Embaadour! before 't's too late,
"And oft revolve Scaevola's noble Fate.
"Carry thee Kies, Seals of my command,
"Unully'd let her have them all at econd hand.
"Goâlet her Roie Mouth, her Balmy Lips,
"(Where Cupid all his golden Arrows dips)
"The warm Virginity of thee Kies tate;
"Goânor thy time, nor their weet odour wate.
"Thee give her, as a Pledge, that I will own
"Thyris a humble Slave to Idera's Throne.
"Goâmy Soul with thee takeâthy Fortune try,
"Dangers and Difficulties all defie,
"What if thou houldt like Codrus, or like Decius die?

q.l: Dicere quae puduit, cribere juit amor.

lg.l: LOng has this grand Mitake deceiv'd Mankind,
To think that Love is only blind;
The Serpent too has lot his Tongue,
When he has any untaught Novice tung.
He leaves his Venom in the rankled Wound,
That cloes up as it were ound,
Spreads out into a bluhing Cheek,
And yet the Lips hard by can nothing peak.
Whether 'tis Ectaie, or Fear, or Zeal,
Whoe prevalent motions thus we feel,
I know not yetâbut this I know,
Thee are my Symptoms, and my Cae is o.
Here in a Hective Fever I mut burn,
And I can neither peak nor turn,
Can neither have nor hope for Eae;
Sure 'tis an Incubus is my Dieae.
Fain would I tell her plainly all my mind,
But neither Tongue, nor Heart can find;
My concious guilt, and modet hame,
In Virgin Red tifle my youthful Flame.
'Tis true my Eyes long ince betray'd their mart,
When Love hot through into my Heart,
When all your Charms took o much pains
T'infue an amorous Heat into my Veins.
Exceive hot, or beyond meaure cold,
My Fits too violent to hold:
By heat, incapable I'm made;
When cold, I am indifferent and afraid.
Turtles for Mates thus one another Prove,
Their Eyes the meaures of their Love.
And thus Pygmalion choe a Wife,
An Ivory Statue carv'd out to the life.

q.l: Hei mihi! quÃ²d nullis amor est medicabilis herbis.

lg.l: HOW oft have I, like wretched Dido, wore
I'd court Incontancy no more?
But 'tis in vain, for I must till adore.
I pluck not up the root, but lop the Tree,
Weave Vows, as Webs, Penelope;
Still tempted I, and till as charming he.
I trive to skin the Wound of Cupid's Dart;
With a new Itch, and tickling Smart,
Still it breaks out again upon my heart.
I pour into the fifty Siter Urn;
And Siyphus his Stone I turn;
Leave off, t' begin again, and quench my elf to burn.
How oft have I dragg'd home my Fugitive?
But till my Heart the lip will give,
My Heart, that cannot without vital Paion live.
With Books and Buines I would entertain,
But Books are toil, and Buines pain:
He's gone I know not how, and all my Art's in vain.
The Oak and Ivy, which together grow,
If parted by an unkind Blow,
Their Arms will about one another throw.
So Birds that now forake their Nets through fear,
When they ome danger ee or hear,
Will build again in the ame place, another year.

div.head: To the Ingenious Mr. Barker. Saul's Witch of Endor.
div.l: A Long and properous Reign had Saul enjoy'd,
With the exces of Peace and Plenty cloy'd,
Of dayly Triumphs and new Trophies proud,
Not one Eclipe, nor melancholy Cloud;
In Peace, his Peoples Guardian, and their Shield,
Always his Arms victorious in the Field;
Fraught with Succes, and paive Duty crown'd,
None that durt quetion his Proceedings, found,
When now for Bloud his thirty Spirits crav'd,
(Like Diomede's Hores) he for Man's fleh rav'd.
His Sword already had been atisfy'd,
Reaking from Enemy's freh Wounds, new dy'd
With purple Gore and a polluted Tide.
Well then for change, th' ungrateful wretch intends
To heath it in the boom of his Friends:
And he mut have that Life, that was laid down
For God's, for Irael's Honour, and the Crown;
When concious Jealouie, and pretended Zeal,
Upon Ambition whet the envious Steel.
David, who did a Miracle for Saul,
Mut tand a Mark for Javilins at the Wall:
Goliah's head, mut make him loe his own,
Becaue he kill'd the Monter, he alone,
With a mall Sling and little Pebble-tone.
Becaue he did that which none ele could do,
Six Cubits with five hundred Shekels lew.
Unhappy Youth! whoe ervice thus repaid
By him that mut have fal'n, without thy aid!
And mut his Life and Kingdom be retor'd,
To kill thee with the ame Victorious Sword?
In what, innocent Youth! couldt thou offend?
A crime to be a Saviour and a Friend?
No Arms wat thou beholden to from Saul;
A little Stone, and Leather Thong was all.
Goliah did not challenge, but defy,
Not only Treaon belch, but Blaphemy:
If to ave Saul's a capital offence,
Thy death be jutify'd by that pretence,
It cannot be imputed in or hame,
To tand up bravely for Jehovah's Name.
Nor can they make out any other Plea,
To tax thee with the leat diloyalty:
For David never yet his Prince forook,
Ambitious only of a Shepherds Crook.
Nothing receiv'd, but what was jutly due,
Nor that, till promis'd once, and proffer'd too.
Here by the way, could I it down, and hed
Whole flouds of Tears for thee, and in thy tead
Lay down my Soul, the Javelin cuts the Air,
And trembling glances through the Champion's hair:
Thou tand't upon thy guard, thy own defence,
Arm'd only with the Mail of Innocence.
Cant unconcern'd, upon thy Muick play,
And to thy Harp again another day.
To ee thy troubles and to trace thy flight,
Unafe by day, yet les ecure by night;
Thy Wife expos'd to danger for thy ake,
Mut one ditracted Vow of Duty break:
Jonathan mut renounce Father, or Friend,
Or ele his life, in death for David pend.
But cauelely we all our Tears impart,
God needs mut love the Image of his heart:
And as he can, he will his Darling ave,
And bury all his troubles in the Tyrant's Grave.
Here then we trut him to th' Almighty's hand,
And the Philitins now invade the Land.
The Scene is chang'd, and for a ingle Flea
Men, like the Sands or Waves upon the Sea,
Gigantick Warriours, Trees for Javelins wield,
And trut along, and challenge all the Field.
What hould Saul do? God and Man perecute;
His Dreams are ilent, and his Prophets mute:
Urim's forgot its old prophetick train,
And Saul's among the Prophets too in vain.
Witches dare only be with Imps poest,
And carry their Familiars in their Breast.
'Tis Death, to draw a Circle in the Sand;
'Tis Death, to have but a Magicians Wand:
Yet for all this (thÃ´ it eem omething odd)
The Devil mut be the Meenger of God.
But hard neceity maintains his Caue,
To break through God's, his own, and Kingdom's Laws.
A Witch, or no Witch, he would only learn
Th'unknown Event of uch a Great Concern.
To Endor then, but not without diguie,
In the extremity of madnes wie;
Where firt on God, he for the Devil does call,
For he was les afraid of him, than Saul,
And with an Oath confirming his deign,
To thee infernal Rites conjures divine.
When to her Cabin now the Witch returns,
Sulphur and Pitch, mixt in a Cauldron, burns:
Infuing Vervain, Moly, Night-hade, Rue,
Then on the Floor five Magick Circles drew,
With gloomy Cypres round her Temples twin'd,
She catter'd dead mens Ahes to the Wind;
Thrice Salt and Bran, Venefick Offerings trow'd,
Pouring out thrice a Black fleec'd Lamb's warm Bloud,
And burning Poeony, Fern, and Heliochrye,
She trikes upon her hollow Cymbal thrice;
And heaving, welling, foaming, then he cries,
With an infernal Howl, Rie, Samuel, rie.
The parting Ground was with Convulions torn,
By ubterraneous Winds he upwards born,
Wrapt in his Prophet's Mantle, like a God,
In a bright Fiery Chariot, whirling rode.
But the Witch trembling at o trange a ight,
And terrify'd with o divine a Light,
Cried out; and what through wonder, and urprize,
Knew not the Fiend auming that diguie.
But eager Saul till preing her to tell
What he had wrought by virtue of the Spell,
Samuel thus preventing ilence broke,
With profound Reverence, in oft Whipers poke.
Saul! Saul! why troublest thou my Soul at rest?
My Soul, to leave the Manions of the Blest?
Why, raiing Tumults thus among the Just,
Offer't thou Violence to my acred Dust?
Why ranacket my Grave? and ummon't me
From my Long Home, Seat of Eternitie?
But Saul, big with Repentance in his Eyes,
And with a Heart as full of Grief, replies:
It was thy Office, Samuel, once to bles;
Cant thou not pity now in my ditres?
When the Philitins dare new Wars proclaim,
Defie my Hots, depie my Royal Name,
Whether to et up David in my Throne,
Or take my Life, God knows, and God alone;
But this I know, God fights againt me too:
What hould a Prince, when thus foraken, do?
By God, by Man cat off, didain'd, forlorn,
My Peoples Burthen, and my Enemy's Scorn;
His Vengeance perecutes me, wretched Saul!
The Cure of God, and a Reproach to all;
My Prophets ilent, and my inpir'd Lute,
Together with my Dreams and Viions, mute:
Therefore it is, by a more powerful Spell,
I call thee up, for thou alone cant tell
What a ditres'd, abandon'd Prince can do;
ThÃ´ God hath left me, let not Samuel too.
Thus trembling Saul bow'd his Anointed Head,
When Samuel thus in hollow Murmurs aid:
Can I, poor Saul! reaon the Cae with God?
Put by the troak of an Almighty Rod?
Can I, without Heaven's licene, tand thy Friend,
If God will?âand he will thy Kingdom rend.
Good David mut and hall thy Scepter way;
Gladly will Irael uch a Prince obey:
More gladly lip thy Yoak from off their neck,
The Yoak thou houldt have put on Amalek;
But him, the Enemy of all that's good,
Glutted with Lust, and urfeited with Blood,
With Blaphemy woln big, corrupt within
With purious Seed of every deadly Sin,
With whom thou houldt have worn immortal hate,
As fale to God, and dangerous to thy State;
That Kingdom thou etablihest by Peace,
Dost Amalek for David's Life releae;
A thouand Shams, to put him by, contrive,
But maugre all, David hall King urvive.
Trut in Supence, hope only in Depair,
Thy Kingdom's won before 'tis lot: Prepare
To meet with Fate; for all thy Hots hall flie,
Thou and thy Sons to morrow be with me.
This aid, urprizing Horror well'd his Veins,
And his ick mind anticipates his pains;
Speechles and cold, he falls upon his Face,
In Frenzy would the fleeting Air embrace,
But Samuel he returns unto his place.

div.head: To Mrs. B. Wright, On her Incomparable Poetry.
div.l: LOng ince my thoughts did thus forboding tell,
The Mues would our Governours expel,
To their own Crown raie up a Female Heir,
One of their Sex the Diadem hould wear:
The time's expir'd, my Jealouie proves true,
We have a Queen, but thanks to Heaven 'tis you;
Before in all things ele we did ubmit,
Madam! in all things ele, but only Wit:
With this Prerogative we could not part,
But in its tead each yielded up his heart.
Such was our vain Self-love and tubborn Pride,
What will not bend, mut break; in vain we try'd
Our Title, nor mut ev'n the Inheritance divide
But now (as Captives to a Conquerour)
We mut urrender all into your power:
With concious Bluhes mut your Praie exert,
Reflecting on our elves in your deert.
Eve firt ought Knowledge from the fatal Fruit;
(Why hould we Vertue to fale ends impute?)
Whilt lazy Adam hrug'd, was very loth
To part with Darling Ignorance and Sloth:
Noble was her deign, had it not been
Branded by Heaven as a preumptuous in.
Your Quest of Knowledge can incur no hame,
Unles ome Mac'line Malice taint your name.
So different as the Caue, are the Effects;
For as he ruin'd, you have rais'd your Sex:
She doom'd to Death, you gain Eternity,
For you mut live until your Works can die.
Had they been like to S.'s Gouty Rhyme,
Or Smithfield-Ballads, in a little time
They'd have been thrown amongt bald muty Songs,
When the young Ballad-Wench had tir'd her Lungs.
But Nature, Judgment, Fancy, Art and Wit,
Shall ooner to one common Fate ubmit,
Than the rich Structures of your Brain hall fall,
Which are the very Quinteence of all.
Nor are you o deirous of the Bays,
As to detract from an inferiour Praie;
But giving us an everlating Name,
You merit to your elf a nobler Fame:
Whilt your own Glory you o much neglect,
And others with uch skill and care protect,
More lating Trophies to your elf erect.
But oh! how high your Fancy takes its flight,
Whilt they admire at you gone out of ight!
So fled Elijah wrapr in Fire and Wind,
And left Eliha wondring here behind:
They like Eliha, for a Bleing call;
You hear their Prayers, and let your Mantle fall.
With this they trange unheard-of things can do,
Had they a Fiery Coach, they'd be Elijah's too.
So did th' aociated Nymphs rejoyce,
Whom Dian had thought worthy of her choice;
So they thÃ´ fair in all the Gods eteem,
Yet made her Beauty far more charming eem.
Let others lander, envy, or depie,
The Cyprian Goddes till mut have the Prize.
Daphne to Laurel turn'd, a Female Brow
Has the bet title to a Female Bough.
Had Fate but plac'd you in the Roman State,
The Salique Law would have been out of date.
By one great labour, but till more would try,
And Heaven, & Earth, and Hell did valorouly defy.
Farther oblige the World, good Madam! till
With the rich products of your fruitful Quill.
Retore the Mues; and true Poetry,
And hew what Charms do in jut meaures lie.
And when you find a time bet to retreat,
Spin out into a curious Web of Wit.
Let me your Mue a Legacy inherit,
With double portion of your acred Spirit.

div.head: A Fragment of Catullus. Advice to Hemiera.
To Madam Aâ Râ.
