lg.l: SEE how the naked widow'd Vine,
That in the empty Vally grows,
That wants the happines to twine
About a Husband's brooding Boughs:
Is without Virtue, Sap, or Juice,
Nor can it raie its drooping head,
Or one mall bunch of Grapes produce,
Or gather trength to bud and pread.
Alas! it ne'er apiring hoots,
For all the help of Wind and Weather,
The tallet Sprigs ev'n touch the Roots,
The Vine tyed neck and heels together.
The churlih Shepherds pluck it up,
Or without notice pas it by;
Nor will the Cattel deign to crop,
Or glance that way one greedy eye.
If wedded to an Elm, they trive
Who can their favours mot improve,
With emulation make it thrive,
All proud to ignalize their Love.
The bluhing Roe, if let alone,
With hame will fade upon the Tree:
A Maidenhead thus over-grown,
Will uperanuated be.

div.head: The PARADOX, To Idera.
div.l: STeichorus, and Orion blind, receiv'd their ight,
One by Apollo's Numbers, th'other by his Light.
Orion basking in his burning Rays;
Had I not, Idera, on you gaz'd, nor of you ung,
I had not lot my Eyes, nor with thoe Eyes my Tongue.

div.head: To Idera, Dreaming he was Angry.

lg.l: FAirer than all the Grecian Dames!
Idera! too too fair!
Thee Touchwood Reliques of my Flames,
For Heaven's ake forbear:
For thÃ´ your Anger at a ditance burn,
My Soul, Love's Tinder, will to nothing turn.
Why would you me from Love diwade?
Why would you tye my Tongue?
My Infant Paion thus upbraid?
Tell me, I am too young?
Oh! why in Viions all my hopes detroy!
Have you forgot that Cupid was a Boy?
If thus in Dreams you can depie!
If thus you can beguile!
Aume a Viard for diguie!
Do any thing but mile!

All the effects of The Weed Heleneius that grows in Rhodes, o call'd from Helen, that hang'd her elf upon an Oak near which it prung up. Whoever tated of it, was provok'd to Anger, Strife, Bawling, and other ill Qualities. Ptolem. Hephaet. l. 4.
Helen's Weed will be,
Paions eential to a Deity.
Ah! Duerates is undone!
Unles your goodnes pare;
For thÃ´ the heat of your bright Sun
He can with pleaure bear,
Yet if your Lightning trike his dazled Eyes,
In horrour and confuion Duerates dies.

div.head: Ovid's Amorum Lib. 3. Eleg. 9. On the death of Tibullus. To Mr. William Lloyd.
div.l: IF Heaven's Eye, the bright Aurora, hrouds
Her troubled Face under a Veil of Clouds,
And every Morning curing her own Womb,
With fragrant Tears bedews her Memnon's Tomb:
If Thetis does her watry Fountains drain,
And with alt roaring Billows fill the Main;
Black Waves, as Mourners, for her Son provide,
And every day lament him with a Tide:
If Deities themelves ubmit to Fate,
Needs mut Mortality ink with uch a weight.
Come, mournful Elegy, with dihevel'd hair,
Sad as thy Stile, thy Face, and hopeles as Depair:
That as too true, thy Nature and thy Name,
So now thy Habit too may be the ame.
So faintly hadow'd in thy penive Face,
Inpir'd ev'n from the Womb with thy own train,
That Soul that ne're conceiv'd a thought in vain;
Thy Pride, thy Heir, thy Glory, and thy Fame,
Thy All is fewel for his fatal Flame.
Poor Cupid for his dear Tibullus mourns,
And carelely his empty Quiver turns;
Puts out his Torch with treaming flouds of Tears,
And broken Arrows for a Trophy rears.
No more his Hymen, nor his IÃ´ ings,
But ighs and obs, and flags his wanton Wings:
With his own Dart cratches and tears his breat,
With the ame Epidemick Rage poet
As Lovers are in Frenzy or Depair,
And digs for his Tibullus eated there.
So for Aeneas mourn'd the lovely Boy,
The Pride of future Rome, and Fame of Troy.
Nor could weet Beauties Queen be troubled more
For her lov'd Youth, torn by a Savage Boar.
Lov'd Youth (aid I) alas! compar'd with thee,
What would a thouand uch Adoni's be?
A Poet's thought ('tis true) to be the Heir
Of Immortality, Heaven's peculiar Care,
Large Souls, a Colony of the Heavenly Line,
With omething amiable and divine;
Nought comes amis to acrilegious Death,
That tops the Impious and the devout Breath.
And no Protection can ecure from Fate,
That loves to prey upon the Good and Great.
What ignified it, Orpheus to be born
Of Gods, by Furies into pieces torn?
With Melody to charm the Beats of Prey,
When men themelves prove greater Bruits than they?
On barren Mountains does the God of Wit,
Mourning in melancholick horror, it
Sighing a broken Tune to his mute Lyre,
And wihes for his Linus to expire.
Homer, that Tree of Knowledge, Greece's Pride,
(That Pegaus whom all the Poets ride)
In life hard Fate depriv'd him of the light,
And after haded with eternal Night,
That unexhauted Spring, to whom we ow
All thoe mall Streams of ours that cattering flow.
His glorious Works, and his adored Name,
Only urvive as proof againt the flame.
For Homer's Troy, that Phoenix cannot die,
So may Penelope's honet guile defie
The envious rage of Time, and reach Eternity.
And o hall Nemeis and Delia prove
As lating in their Fame as in their Love:
Delia, that firt his youthful Paion warm'd,
And Nemeis that lat and longet charm'd.
In vain to lazy Gods we duly pray,
And to their Shrines our contant Homage pay.
In vain we deaf or helples Stocks implore,
Or drowie dreaming Deities adore,
That neither will have pity nor regard;
And righteous Souls can merit no Reward,
But turn like Bruits unto their native Dut.
What reaon then have we to run on trut?
I'm tempted to believe no God, or Heaven's unjut.
Live well, and die well, there's an end of one;
And why hould I the foolih hazard run
Of being vertuous, when I may as well
In flouds of Pleaures wim the way to Hell?
Death drags us from the Altar to the Grave,
Whilt careles Heaven looks on and will not ave.
Death makes no Sanctuary of any place,
To whom, when, where, he comes, 'tis all a cae:
The Laws of Fate, without exceptions, made
Irrevocable, needs mut be obey'd.
Is Pluto blind? what then? the blind can hear:
And cannot Veres charm the Tyrant's Ear?
If o, would our Tibullus thus have died?
Tibullus Beauty's Prince, the Poet's Pride?
See now, of that Great Man the mall Remains
A little narrow Urn in Dut contains.
How durt the flames (dear Friend) accot that breat
With uch an hallow'd Vetal Fire poet?
What dare not they, that Vengeance can provoke,
And down with Gods and Temples at a troke?
The Queen of Love with pity, and with dread,
At uch Preumption turn'd away her head;
Nay ome affirm, the Deity preent there,
Could carce from melting drops of Tears forbear.
Yet thanks to Heaven that thou diedt at home,
Corcyra could not be o weet as Rome.
Thy Mother here clos'd thy departing Ey's,
And et that Sun that never more would rie.
In the cold hands of unrelenting death,
Gather'd the fragrant Reliques of thy breath,
And paid her lat Devotion to thy Urn:
With her thy Siter did in Conort mourn;
For thee he did her lovely Trees tear,
For thee in flouds of tears he wah'd her catter'd hair
And when too forward on thy way to Blis,
Delia and Nemeis ecur'd a Kis:
A Kis (aid I!) millions they laid in tore,
Since they were never like to ee thee more;
Some of thy parting breath they did receive,
And for each Sob a thouand Kies give,
Kies on which they might for ever live.
The Rivals both with emulous paion tay,
Until the Flames had raviht thee away.
Thus Delia parting, for he left him firt,
(The Wounds of Boom-friends are always wort)
"'Twas I that eaon'd firt thy untaught heart,
"And did the ecret Rites of Love impart.
"Hadt thou been true, Albius, thou hadt not died;
"But thank thy own incontancy and pride,
"One and the ame Divorce did me and life divide.

"
Vengeance has found thee out in my defence,
"And took the part of injur'd Innocence.
"Ah! that thou hadt but thy own interet known,
"And lov'd thy Delia, and lov'd her alone.
But Nemeis with Tears, (reolv'd to prove
She had bet right and title to his Love)
Repliesâ
â"To me Grief only does belong,
"And if you hed a Tear, you do me wrong.
"Long ince your Tyranny you did reign,
"Tibullus ince was mine, and only mine.
"He grap'd me in his Arms, and held me fat,
"Nor would he let me go, whilt breath would lat.
"When Death's Convulions Nature's Fabrick tore,
"His Organs loos'd, and he could peak no more,
"In broken Accents this I heard him breath,
"My Soul into thy arms, my Nemeis, I bequeath.
If there be ought of us urvives the Flames,
Ought of us but our hadows and our names,
T' Elyium hall Tibullus be convey'd,
And there his Soul become the brightet Shade.
There halt thou Calvus and Catullus find,
(About his Temples acred Ivy twin'd:)
There in thoe Regions of Eternal Day,
If Fame belie him, (as I wih it may)
Shalt thou Tibullus with thy Gallus meet,
And your trange hades your former loves repeat.
Gallus, inpir'd with an ambitious Flame!
Gallus, too prodigal of Life and Fame!
But whilt his Shade wanders amongt the Jut,
Thou Urn be careful of thy precious Trut,
Nor let his acred Ahes touch the common Dut.
Lie light, thou Earth, indulgent to his ret,
Whilt his great Soul converes with the Blet.

div.head: To Idera, Having by ome Michance o hurt her elf as to halt.

lg.l:
Ceres in her Travels over all the World, in quet of her Daughter Proerpine, that was tole away by Pluto, meeting with Neptune, who by his troubleome company increaed her grief, he turn'd her elf into a Mare, and coming to Styx, a River in Arcadia, where he aw her Face, he dyed the Water of a black colour. Ptolem. Hephaet. Lib. 3.
CEres in quet of Proerpine,
Seeing th' reflexion of her Face,
Not as 'twas formerly divine,
Grief dipoeing every Grace;
She unconcern'd at uch a ight,
Yet made her Glas the Stygian Lake,
To mourning turn her crytal white,
And of her Grief the Streams partake.
Bluh not, weet Nymph! thÃ´ envious Fate,
Proud on your Feet to et a mark;
Let them that dare provoke your hate,
Not at your Altar light a park.
Vulcan was lame, althÃ´ a God:
(Nor must the Truth be always aid)
Let them not kis the Ground you trod,
Scrupulous Fools! but trike them dead.
Timorous Fate, like Diomede,
Struck Venus on the lower parts:
They that dare make the Wound to bleed,
Set hungry Vultures at their hearts.
Set them a Mark for your fair Eye,
And kill them, kill them with Depair,
They need not with wore Torments die,
Than to ee Heaven, but not come there.
When Nature, with Ambition fir'd,
Some trange and wondrous thing deign'd,
And to out-do her elf apir'd,
She took you out of Womankind.
All their Perfections knit in one,
Thy Soul preented from above,
Jealous to ee her elf out-done,
With her own Works he fell in love.
Cupid could carce his Mother know,
Venus and Idera were o like;
But Fate with a deciding Blow,
The Mark on Idera's ide did trike.
Yet thanks to Fate, whoe common Brand
Has et us both on even ground;
Yet thanks to Fate, whoe heavy hand
Could forbear a mortal Wound.
Achilles by an Arrow fell,
Struck through his heel, whilt you till live,
With Scars that can your Valour tell,
And yet a thouand Deaths can give.
A thouand cas'd within my Breast,
Glance Idera a diolving Smile,
If you would have them dipoet,
Or with the Quiver of my Heart recoil.

div.head: To Mr. Omnibon.
A Diwaive from that Effeminate Paion of Love.
div.l: OFF (Thyris!) with this melancholick Fit,
Nor like a Purgatory Freh-man it;
In love, my Thyris, and pretend't to Wit!
What, reconcil'd! and cant thou not forbear?
What, pardon thoe that did to pieces tear
Thy Brother Orpheus? what, not Love forwear?
Love, that damn'd Leproie, infectious Pest,
All Africa's Monters kennell'd in his breat.
Tell me not 'tis a in to break your Vows
Of Lovers, perjury Jove himelf allows.
Noâhe's an As that Womankind adores:
Let Bacchus kick the Batard out of doors.
Come then dip the blind Rogue in a full Bowl,
And let Wine's Spirits elevate your Soul.
For Love will vanih at his Brother's ight,
So Phoebus dims the Lamps that rule the Night:
So Antidotes rank Poyon can expel:
And o one Witch undoes another's Spell:
So Muick helpeth when Tarantula's ting;
And Orpheus can as well as Sirens ing.

div.head: To Idera, Writing her Name in Snow, which melting to Water, froze, and oon after thaw'd.
div.l: YOur Name on fallen Snow I eal'd;
The melting drops to Ice congeal'd:
In Crytal Prints the Letters hine,
And their material white refine.
Here daily, hourly as I pas
By this heavenly Looking-glas,
I ee the picture of my Face,
And the reflecting Name embrace.
But as by Images of Wax
The Witch a real Body racks;
So as my Heart within conumes,
Ice Snow, Snow Water, reaumes.
My Flames do all your Cold withdraw,
Till we reolve on better Law,
That you hall never freeze, to thaw.
For thus well arm'd, you can defie
A thouand Deaths at once let flie,
Laugh to ee Duerates die.
With your Temptations, millions trong,
To do me right, you do me wrong.
Nayâev'n with Chymical Experiments entice:
Your very Name can make a Burning-glas of Ice.

div.head: A Propitiatory Sacrifice, To the Ghot of Jâ Mâ by way of Patoral, in a Dialogue between Thyris and Corydon.
To his dear Brother Mr. Ah Wyndham.

sp.speaker: THYRSIS.
sp.l: GOod morrow, Corydon! but why o trange?
What makes your jolly Countenance thus change?
What, have you lot a Kid? or pine and mourn
For Galatea's lights, or Amarylli's corn?
Did melancholy Dreams diturb your ret?
Eae then on me the burthen of your breat,
A hearty Friend will not your Grief depie,
And Thyris will be proud to ympathize.

sp.speaker: CORYDON.
sp.l: Ah, Thyris! ee, after unpleaant food,
The very Cows will chew no bitter Cud;
Can my repeated Sorrows do thee good?
And yet for thee my Grief will I controul,
For thee I'll offer Violence to my Soul:
Know then, nor need I give that Caution, weep,
Thy Eyes are neither drie, nor Heart aleep:
Know then, the rie of it is Daphny's death;
And ince the Fates have topt my Daphny's breath,
I have my Pipes, my Flocks, my Loves forwore,
And well I might, ince he is now no more.

sp.speaker: THYRSIS.
sp.l: When the Day's Lamp's hadow'd before the Night's,
And pangled Heaven ets out her glittering Lights,
Sweet Philomel her little Throat does tune,
And charm with warbling Notes the litning Moon.
When the harp watchful Thorn has gor'd her breat,
And bleeding Philomel can take no ret:
So may your Mue unfledg'd yet try her Wing,
And Grief and Love joyntly together ing.
So may we well pull up the Sluces of our Eyes,
For Death has topt the Springs of Paradie;
Which in profue Meanders curling ran,
Baptiz'd us Poets, and gave life to Man.
For Death has eiz'd our Mint of learned Ore,
And weep'd away all our Poetick tore.
So when an ancient Oak falls on the ground,
The Woods all tremble, and the Rocks reound;
Nor falls alone, but hovering in the Air,
A thouand little Fates the Branches bear.
Arcadians mourn! Daphnis a publick los,
And well may all our Tears and Grief engros.
Sound then his Obequies, Daphnis deceat!
Come ing away the burthen of thy Breat,
For he deerves thy Song, and well deerves the best.
Or both alternately our parts will ing,
You hall the Laurel, I the Myrtle bring.

sp.speaker: CORYDON.
sp.l: Ord'nary Tears ufficient are to fall
Attendants of a common Funeral:
Daphnis deerves for each a drop of Blood,
And for each ingle drop a carlet Flood.
As Nightingales ing weeter than the Thruh;
The Cedar's better than the Bramble-buh;
Sweet Marjoram and Musk, than tinking Weeds;
Daphnis our Merit and our Praie exceeds.
The Elm for Daphnis groans, will let the Vine
No more in his embraces fondly twine.
Bees leave their Flowers, which droop their ickly head,
Have lot their weet repast on which they fed,
Since he whoe breath inpir'd it all, is dead.
Our Flocks all keep a Fast for Daphnis ake:
Our Ile the weet-tongu'd Chanters too forake.
None but the inaupicious Ravens croke,
The Nymphs and Demy-Gods their Pipes have broke,
And bid adieu to all their Fairy Kings.
The Scriech Owl howts, and the black Swallow ings.
Nature her elf puts on her Mourning-Weed.
One Wound makes the whole Univere to bleed.

sp.speaker: THYRSIS.
sp.l: As Day without the propect of the Sun,
As Night without the conduct of the Moon,
Such, Daphnis, is the World, now thou art gone!
For Daphnis, too too well belov'd of Heaven,
Only to teach us Self-denial given,
Is dead alas! O Paradox! is dead,
Voracious Grave! and conecrated Head!
What, could not Daphnis charm ambitious Death,
From gathering all the Reliques of his breath?
Could He not ev'n the Powers of Hell defy,
And by oft Airs bring them to Harmony?
Been omething more than Mortal? NoâHard Fate
Spares not the Rich, the Good, the Wie, the Great.
The proudet Dut mut hid in ilence lie:
The proudet Dust must in oblivion die.

sp.speaker: CORYDON.
sp.l: ThÃ´ Fortune acted oft the Stepdame's part,
Yet would not Daphnis cure her in his heart:
ThÃ´ Gall infus'd into his bitter Cup,
Taught by Philoophy, he drank it up.
Ah too too oon a hining Cherub made
Of that blet place thou hadt o long urvey'd!
My Mue mut tell the Groves Great Daphnis dead!
Whilt pining Eccho anwers what is aid:
Eccho for him mut die a econd death,
Us'd to retort his words, and uck his fragrant breath.

sp.speaker: THYRSIS.
sp.l: Trees full of Tears hide their heads, bowing down,
All Rivals once which hould be made his Crown:
All proudly concious of their welcome Shade,
Where Judgment, Wit, and Innocence were laid:
Nure of his Thought, and Midwife of his Brain,
That fruitful teeming Womb that knew no pain;
But brought the well-digeted Product forth,
Pregnant with joy, and boating uch a Birth.
Nor mut we here his forward Youth forget,
To pay whoe Portion Nature ran in debt.
So oon the Bard, and o divine a hare
He well deerv'd, who was her only Heir,
Her Darling-Son, and her peculiar Care.
He could teach Reverend Sages how to write,
And precribe Rules ev'n to the God of Wit.
(Like Tages) born a Poet from the Womb,
And ung himelf from 's Cradle to his Tomb.
Inpir'd with Melody, with his firt breath,
Improving Art and Learning, till his death.
Still as his annual Circles rowl'd about,
They unknown Worlds of Sciences found out.
Here only Mother Nature, for his ake,
Did her own Laws out of Indulgence break,
From Youth and Age one piritual Compound make.
But when his Age and Fruit together ripe,
(Of which blind Homer only was the Type)
Tireias like, he mounted up on high,
And corn'd the filth of dull Mortality.
Convers'd with Gods, and grac'd their Royal Line,
All Ectaie, all Rapture, all Divine.

sp.speaker: CORYDON.
sp.l: So the Philoopher would needs be blind,
T' improve the nobler Eye-ight of his Mind,
Not to mean earthly Opticks be confin'd.

sp.speaker: THYRSIS.
sp.l: No wonder, if th' ambitious Laurel's dead,
Degraded to a Mercenary Head.
If Birds forget their Notes, and it alone,
With melancholy Progne in the Deerts moan,
Since this our Bird of Paradie is flown.
Daphnis! the great Reformer of our Ile!
Daphnis! the Patron of the Roman Stile!
Who firt to ence converted Doggrel Rhimes,
The Mues Bells took off, and topt their Chimes,
On urer Wings, with an immortal flight,
Taught us how to believe, and how to write.
And could we but have reach'd his wondrous height,
We'd chang'd the contitution of our State.
Where Reaon mut enlightned Souls confute,
To common Earth 'tis till forbidden Fruit:
For all in Torrents his Inventions flow,
And drown the little Vales that lie below.
And yet o weet, Malice would ilenc'd die;
So perfect, they could Prejudice defie.
Daphnis! whoe Modety might jutly boat,
His Errours leat, his Excellencies mot.
Well might we bluh at every acred Line,
To ee a Soul o Humble, o Divine.
But I offendâand whilt I praie his Stile,
Do in Apotate Rhimes his Worth defile.
His Guardian Angel does begin to frown,
His Spirit looks with indignation down.

sp.speaker: CORYDON.
sp.l: Ev'n Tombs of Stone in time will wear away;
Bras Pyramids are ubject to decay;
But lo! the Poet's Fame hall brighter hine
In each ucceeding Age,
Laughing at the baffled Rage
Of envious Enemies, and detructive Time.

sp.speaker: THYRSIS.
sp.l: Ret Phoenix! in thy Paradie above,
Thy Works enjoy a Paradie of Love:
ThÃ´ ome with a rank emulous Poyon well,
Others admire, and praie, but none excel.
May our poor Rutick Mue add Cyphers to thy Fame.
Thy Works are everlating Monuments to thy Name.

div.head: Oldham's GHOST. A Dream. To Mr. Ro. Townhend.
div.l: ALL huht and till, Night's melancholy hade
The dusky Arch of Heaven had overpread;
The very Beats of Prey their Wandrings ceat;
The little Birds their murm'ring Notes uppret:
No Star appear'd, no Noie, no Wind was heard,
And neither Bough, nor Leaf, nor Bloom tir'd.
When on the weating ground I ilent lay
On Flowery Beds under a fragrant Bay,
Whoe weetnes uck'd my emulous breath away.
Now parting with my Reaon and my Sence,
Slumbers as oft, as weet as Innocence,
Had eiz'd my Eyes, and the great God of Rest
Had drawn his drowie Wand along my Breat.
Methought I aw an Angel by me tand,
With Laurels on his head and Myrtles in his hand.
And all the way the Meenger of God
Had with his hallow'd Feet in Glory trod:
Sprung up Elyian Flowers here and there,
Sweet as their Climate, as their Parent fair.
His heavenly Locks lay curl'd by Nature's Arts:
A Quiver for his Brother Cupid's Darts,
Sweating Ambroian Dew: His Eyes too bright:
His Roes were too red: his Lillies were too white.
His Smiles kind entertainment did bepeak,
His Smiles pread in a pleaant Lip and bluhing Cheek:

l.U: miles not half o weet as they,

div.l: AlthÃ´ he lov'd, and mil'd himelf away.
Preumption yet they check'd, I know not how,
With a Majetick Cenure on his Brow.
So weet a Cherub of the Heavenly Quire!
The Gods themelves did their own Works admire.
Thus tood the winged Mercury, array'd
In Purple Robes of Stateâ
Which to his Buskins reach'd, kis'd them, and with them play'd.
Thus tood the Prophet, preing me to take
A Vizard, and a Book, for Oldham's ake.
By which I knew I had acceptance found;
And falling down, I kit the Holy Ground.
But he proceeded thusâfor I was dumbâ
"Hail Thyris! little Bud of Fame! I come
"Fraught with an Embaie, ent from above,
"An Embaie of Favour, Grace, and Love.
"Thy Wih is enter'd in the Rolls of Fate:
"Thy Prayers are heard, nor fear thou halt be great.
"Thy Parts the only Talent Heaven will give,
"(On uch a Portion Prodigals might live.)
"ThÃ´ Honour is not in the leat thy aim,
"Yet Wits a hunting, often light on Fame.
"Friends thou halt have, but few, faithful, and free,
"As thou deir't, deerv't, if that can be.
"Wedded to a young Widow Colledge-life,
"Thy Books thy Children, and thy Mue thy Wife.
"And ince thou dot only invoke my Mue,
"Me and my Works for thy ole Pattern chue:
"By my own elf I wear, thou halt inherit
"A double Portion of Apollo's Spirit.
"Nor my adopted Son! when thus retir'd,
"(The Bleing which thou hat o long deir'd)
"Shalt thou not find a heart to lah the Crimes,
"The bold notorious Strumpets of the Times.
"Nor halt thou want a Telecope from far:
"Deep Caves alone by day decry a Star.
"Secure from danger on the ilent hore,
"The horrour of a Storm others ee more,

"
Than they, that without hope and help complain,
"And loe their ene in the Abys of pain:
"By ad experience their own miery find;
"Can't utter the confuion of their mind;
"But wallow'd up, plunge deeper in Depair;
"Carry'd they know not how, they know not where.
"My Works hall both thy Mint and Optick be;
"Here at one propect thou halt all things ee:
"All things Sarcatical, that jutly fall
"Under that common head, compendious All.
"My Works hall be thy Forge to form thy Skill:
"The World finds Matter, and thy elf a Will.
"Improve thy Worth, Worth is it elf a Name:
"Trace but my Stile, and you ecure my Fame.
"Satyr's a plain, Satyr's a pleaant Road,
"Provided that the way be not too broad.
"But in a full career 'tis hard to mis
"Running upon a dangerous Precipice.
"Be neither trivial, nor take too much pains;
"Let Malice never guide your furious Reins.
"When grave, be not elaborate, nor write
"For olid, intricate: for eaie, light:
"Thee and the ret for your intruction learn,
"And between good and evil to dicern.
This aid, rapt in an Ectafie of Love,
Fed with vain hopes, I would my Viion prove.
Of blind Deluions in fale Dreams afraid,
Strove to embrace the Evangelick Shade.
When lo! he vanih'd from my dazled Eyes,
And thus my filial Love, and thus my Duty did depie.
Fanning his ilver Wings, he cut the Sky,
Which gathering in thick fleecy throngs, did fly
To ee the great Embaadour of Heaven pas by.
And where the Clouds parted to give him way,
My Cries did pot along as fat as they.
My Father! Father! kept the Chariots track,
Hung on the Wheels, and would have brought him back,
But left o far behind, I tart and wake.

div.head: On The Death of the late Duke of Ormond.

q.l: Ipe tibi jam brachia contrahit ardens
Scorpius, & coeli jutÃ¢ plus parte reliquit.

div.head: To Mr. William Butler.
div.l: UNder a fatal Yew, as I was laid,
Pleas'd with the dimal melancholick Shade,
Democritus in a black Veil appears,
Democritus his Ghost in flouds of Tears.
Horrour my Senes in confuion eal'd,
The icy current of my Bloud congeal'd.
Each Joynt and Sinew loos'd: my welling Veins
Were cold and tiff, bound on the Rack of Pains.
Smother'd in ilence thus I panting lay,
And heard the hollow Specter ighing ay,
He's goneâthe Pillar of the Church and State
With honour inks under the mighty weight;
The Britih Atlas falls a Sacrifice to inulting Fate.
Who would not ev'n the Laws of Nature break?
And be a Polyzaelus a Cyrenian, who never laughed. v. Ptolemaeus Hephaet. Lib. 3. Polyzaelus for his ake?
Democritus, the lightet Mould of Earth,
Whoe Life was one continu'd Scene of Mirth,
A Deluge of religious Tears mut hed,
To wah the Hero; for a Hero's dead.
Fame! thou chief Attribute of his great Soul!
Proclaim the doleful News from Pole to Pole:
Employ thy hundred Tongues, that all may come,
And pay their lat Devotion to his Tomb.
Here at this Agelatos, a Stone o called from Ceres her orrow for the los of her Daughter, not far from the Well Callichorus. v. Apollod. Lib. 1. Cap. 5. Â§ 1. Agelatos igh and groan,
Till Niobe's fate more jutly be their own.
Let Nature her unhappy los bewail,
And hide her head under a Widow's Veil:
Or like Evadne, with her Husband burn,
As he to Ahes, he to Chaos turn.
The Sun and Moon eclips'd!âwhere am I now?
Stars clahing fall!âthe inking Heavens bow!
The Sun and Moon would Ormond both embrace!
The Sun and Moon would both reign their place:
The Contellations all together croud,
And hide themelves behind a bahful Cloud!
The Signs contracted, hrink to make him room!
Concern'd where Ormond will vouchafe to come!
Each for the honour of his preence vy!
Yet bluh Ormond hould have no Rival in the Sky!
Hah! what trange Light is this that trikes my Eyes,
And from thoe Mits of Darknes eems to rie!
âWhat blazing Comet's that I ee
Newly intall'd chief in the Galaxy!
Pereus and Caiopeia round him twine,
To blind his Lutre, both their Forces joyn;
But he does all the heavenly Hot out-hine!
'Tis Ormond, by that Spotles Robe of white!
Nor could another Sign be half o bright!
'Tis Heâinert him in your Kalendar,
A worthy Saint, and an aupicious Star.
Thou World, alternately rejoyce and mourn,
But rather drop more Tears into his Urn:
Whilt I to my own elf and to my place return.

div.head: To Mr. R. Nichols. On the Little Man that was how'd for a Sight all over England. In imitation of a Greek Epigram out of Lucilius.
div.l: A Grave Philoopher of old, that taught
The World at firt was out of Atoms brought,
Had Fate projected in his time, thy Birth;
When Epicurus thus conceiv'd the Earth;
He would have made the Univere of thee:
As much les than diminutive Atoms be.
Or this at leat he would for granted take,
Heaven did out of thee thoe Atoms make.
Man, the World's Microcom, all allow:
The Microcom of an Atom Thou!

epigraph.q: Let him kis me with the kies of his mouth.

div.head: To Mrs. Mary Nichols.
div.l: WHat Angel's voice thus ecchoes thrÃ´ the Sky,
Thus rowls along, and breaks in Harmony?
Rejoyce, rejoyce, for thy Redemption's nigh.
Ah! what oft welcome Airs alute my Ears!
Airs! that enchant the Stars, and charm the Spheres!
The Clouds all melt away! ucceeding Light
And glorious Pomp dazle my fixed ight!
The Elements give back, and bow the knee,
Whilt Seraphs dance unto the Melody;
But I alone tand weeping by the Tree:
Not yet the Tree of Life, a melancholy Cros;
There eek for Remedy, and bewail my los.
For in my Saviour's abence, that long while,
Nothing could force, no not a feigned mile;
Nor make me blot the Copy he had et,
Whoe Eyes were never wanton, often wet;
Whoe Sufferings Agonies, drops of Bloud his Sweat.
But now He's come! the Herald did proclaim,
And bow'd with Reverence at his Sacred Name.
My ravih'd Soul fell down before his Throne,
And now I knew it was the Holy One.
'Twas my Beloved I had ought o long,
Whom I had found, had I not ought him wrong.
And art thou come?âAnd is it thou, blet Dove?â
Can I believe my Eyes, or trut my Love?
Pardon, dear Jeu! uch a jealous Faith;
ThÃ´ weak my Trust, my Love's as trong as Death.
Pardon me too, for ince I aw thee lat,
The Flouds have laid my fruitful Garden wat.
Alas! what pleaure could a Widow take,
Who only lov'd that Garden for thy ake!
What's all the ret, when Sharon's Roe is gone?
The Roe that's all my Garden's Sweets in one?
Let me but hugg that Roe within my Breat,
And then, my Love! let who's will take the ret.
Noâthat has lain all open to the South,
And I have only kis'd thy hands and feet;
Now kis me with the kies of thy mouth,
The kies of thy mouth, for they are weet!
My Spoue, let me uck up thy fragrant breath,
For ah! my Love's as trong as Wine or Death.
For a Kis for our lat parting I mut ue;
And one at meeting jutly is my due.
Pay all thy Debts for abence, thee and more,
With uury pay off that divine Score.
Do not my Paion, O my Spoue! didain,
Nor let my Sighs and Tears be all in vain:
But give me Balmy Kies in exchange,
Nor let unhappy Abence make thee trange.
Comeâlet us trive which firt their Lips can joyn,
Which can the cloet to their Rivals twine;
Until our trugling Spirits both releae,
Till thee our Seconds make a perfect peace.
Victorious Captives both with joy return,
Both with new Love and Emulation burn.
As for my Soul, thou halt new life inpire,
In gratitude with zeal I'll blow the Fire.
Come thenâdear Jeu! comeâand no more part,
But take the full poeion of my Heart.

div.head: To Idera, The Apology for Silence.

lg.l: LOng has the Store-houe of my heart
Been laying Fewel in;
Here and there Cupid's left a Dart,
The fire for Matches to begin.
But my Combutibles, as yet
Have not their Caverns broke:
And whilt they can no paage get,
Send only Vollies out of Smoke.
Yet by thee Sparks you might have guet
What Balls of Flames do rowl
Within the Furnace of my Breat,
And ev'n conume my melting Soul.
Veuvius hollow Entrails glow,
Red-hot with hidden Fire;
And yet they nothing upwards throw,
Their tock of Flames which once a year
They pour upon the fruitful Plain;
Their Forge of loads of Ahes clear,
And to their Smithy work again.
ThÃ´ Preludes yet I only hew,
Nor tell you all my mind,
Idera! trut me to be true,
And think, my Fair One! th' more's behind.

div.head: The Dumb Dicovery.
To Idera.
div.l: THÃ´ Cupid flames from Vulcan tole,
And made a Bonfire of my Soul;
Reolv'd from Aetna to remove,
There to et up his Forge for Love:
With this perwaion prepoet,
That Flames pent in a narrow Breat,
Would dipatch ooner poyon'd Darts,
None o hot as Lovers hearts:
Yet thought I none this Shop can know,
Hid, like Aetna, under Snow.
None upect, an outward Styx
With Phlegeton under ground hould mix:
But my Ahes all betray,
And to my Work houe hew the way.
Thus the Philoopher, who fraught
With an ambitious fury, thought
To be intall'd a God, by night
Took downwards an immortal flight:
By his decenion would apire
Through the burning Mount, in fire:
Aetna, to undeceive the World,
His Iron Slippers upwards hurl'd.
He, greedy to advance his Name,
Beguil'd at once of Life and Fame.

div.head: In praie of Wine mixt with Water. A Greek EPIGRAM, Out of Meleager.
To Mr. Francis Nichols.
div.l: THE Nymphs, when Bacchus, like an Embryo, came
Out of his Mother's Ahes, on a flame,
Dipt the young Deity in a cool tream,
To quench the fire, and take away the team.
The Nymphs and Bacchus ever ince agree,
Without the Nymphs, Thunder and Lightning He!
Thus Water moderates the rage of Wine,
And Fire it elf proves cool and anodyne.
Wine all the Waters crudities conumes;
Water feeds on her hot and heady fumes:
To one another both a flavour give,
And make a Cordial of a Corroive.

lg.l: DOwn by a River's ide together at
Thyris and Hylas, (uch was once the State
Of our First Parents, in a friendly Strife,
Thus Innocence might learn to quare her life)
Where inging Waters lull'd themelves aleep:
And clouded Heaven did ympathizing weep.
When penive Thyris thus did ilence break,
And all in Tears to his lov'd Hylas peak.

sp.speaker: THYRSIS.
sp.l: And cant thou, Hylas, thou, be o unkind
Thus to leave me and Life behind?
And cant thou think of me without regret?
On Love's account for millions run in debt?

sp.speaker: HYLAS.
sp.l: No Thyris! Hylas can't uncontant prove,
Nor have I yet been wavering in my Love;
But emulous Fate ummons us both to part:
Hat thou not a ufficient Pledge, my Heart?

sp.speaker: THYRSIS.
sp.l: Yet out of ight I hall be out of mind:
Ah! Hylas, hould you prove unkind,
Officious Fate would need no other Knife
To cut in two my ravell'd Thread of Life.

sp.speaker: HYLAS.
sp.l: Nature her elf hall firt unhinged be;
The whole Creation loe its Symmetry:
Iron th' attractive Loadtone hall forake,
When I the acred League of Friendhip break.

sp.speaker: THYRSIS.
sp.l: Into a confus'd Chaos hall be hurl'd
The hatter'd Atoms of the World:
The Needle too the Northern point hall hun:
And with my Promie Rivers backwards run.

sp.speaker: HYLAS.
sp.l: To Hylas then be ure you never fail
Kies to end by every gentle Gale.
Let Hylas be your talk, Hylas your Dreams:
Tranport me Sighs over the Belgick Streams.

sp.speaker: THYRSIS.
sp.l: To Thyris, without intermiion, pay
Your bounden Duty night and day;
And nothing les to Thyris, than to Heaven,
For Life and Love by both alike are given.
Pray to the Gods; but I can hardly ay
Whether to them you firt preume to pray:
Noâyour firt and lat thoughts mut be my due.
Come, Hylas! then once more renew
Your everlating Vow, before your long Adieu.

sp.speaker: HYLAS.
sp.l: I wear by all the Thunderbolts of Jove;
By thoe revengeful Darts of injur'd Love:
By Life and Death, and all the Powers above;
To comprehend them all, I wear by You,
That I for ever will be just and true.

lg.l: May all the Plagues that Vengeance has in tore
For Infidelity, thee and more,
With Aggravations, light on perjur'd Me,
If I be guilty of Uncontancy.
Or if an Action be againt me brought,
Of one upicious Deed, or doubtful thought.
This aid, ravih'd into an Ectaie,
They would in their perfection die;
And trugling hardly to themelves can come,
Like Prophets with their Inpiration dumb.
Cupid the heavenly Mediator came,
And with two Arrows dipt in Honours Flame,
Their golden points piercing through both their hearts,
For tryal of their Faith and Vertue, parts.
Hylas the Seas to Holland troubled bore,
And left deerted Thyris ighing on the hore.

div.head: A Greek EPIGRAM.
To Idera.
div.l: SHot by th' Artillery of your fair Eye,
So great my pains, I would, but cannot die:
Sicilian Tyrants never yet could Death deny!
Tears from my feter'd Wound, like Matter, flow,
And till the Fire you will not quench, but blow.
What hall I do? I've ranack'd Nature's tore,
She has no Plantain for a Lover's Sore:

Leucas, a Rock o called from Leucus one of the Companions of Ulyes, who was lain by Antiphus, as Homer tells the Story. Whooever leap'd down from the top of this Rock, was freed from the lavery and tyranny of Love, as Jupiter, Venus, Artemiia, Hippomedon, and everal others experienc'd. See the reaon of this wonderful Vertue, that was o peculiar to this Rock, given by Ptolemaeus Hephaetion. Lib. 7. Leucas the only Remedy is no more.
Ah! Madam, you, and only you can ave,
Your Beauty that mut heal the Wound it gave.
I'm Telephus, you have Achilles Arms,
You have, and know you have all their inherent Charms.

However, let me not like Hercules upon ome quarrel with the Centaurs for broaching a new Hoghead of their Wine for his own drinking, as he hot at Elatus one of their company, the Arrow truck through his arm into his Friend Chiron's knee; who by reaon of his immortality, was forc'd to endure a great deal of miery; but at lat was releas'd, being permitted to change life for death with Prometheus. v. Apollodor Lib. 2. Cap. 4. Â§ 4. Chiron lie

q.l: Curing my elf, and you, and Immortalitie!

Quam procul incautam nemora inter Creia fixit

Pator agens telis, liquit
que volatile ferrum

que peragrat

div.head: On John Pig, who was very famous for his great NOSE.
To Mr. R. Nichols.
div.l: TO ay, the Noe of Pig! that cannot be;
There's no comparion, 'tis all Hyperbole!
But he that would the naked Truth expoe,
Mut for ditinction ay, Pig of the Noe!

div.head: Part of the 14th Satyr of Juvenal, Against Covetounes: With a long Preface taken out of the ame Satyr.

q.l: Et quando uberior vitiorum copia? quando
Major Avaritiae patuit inus?

div.head: To Mr. Will. Percival.
div.l: TOO many things (Cenorius!) there be
That do entail an endles Infamy,
That brand a man with a deerved hame,
And poil the lutre of an honet Name,
Which Parents to their Children do tranmit,
And ground them in before their Alphabet.
'Tis no uch wonder now-a-days to ee
How liquorih a little Boy will be,
Still craving change of Dainties to invite
A queamih Stomach to an Appetite,
Didaining hearty Fare, and wholome Meat,
Conulting with Apicius what to eat;
When the old toothles Grandire with his Gums
Mumps Muhrooms, Marmalade, and Sugar-plums;
Sucks from Herculean Bowls the choicest Wines,
And does whatever Luxury enjoyns:
Go, cries that Lut, he runs: Come, and he'll fly:
What Belly-God his Palate can deny?
No wonder if the Son preciely tread
In the ame path where his good Father led.
If he's for this and t'other cotly Bit,
Can down with nothing but what's delicate;
And by Tradition keeps to the old Wih,
A Princely Kitchin, and a Dainty Dih.
Thus Nature binds us by too hard a Law;
Dometick patterns eaily withdraw;
Led by the Ignis Fatuus of their Vice,
We make no quetion but they must be wie,
And we fall on, refuing to be nice:
Loth to be made Subjects for Ridicule,
Single exceptions from a Common Rule.
But mot when great Authorities enforce,
We hurry on, and follow the ame coure,
And trive, if poible, to be much wore.
Some few there be more vertuouly inclin'd,
Whom Titan made of Clay the best refin'd,
Whom Titan has inpir'd with a more generous mind:
Who corn by evil Precepts to be way'd,
And by authentick wickednes betray'd,
Whilt others keep the track their Ancetors have made.
The generality go the common Road,
In which their bigotted Forefathers trod,
Conidering not the way's too eaie and too broad.
Abtain from Vice, if nothing ele can move,
ThÃ´ other Reaons inufficient prove,
Let this prevail, a Father's Duty, and a Father's Love.
Let your Poterity imitating you,
Quote your Authority for what they do;
Your vile Example hould infect the Times,
And you mut bear your own and others Crimes.
There is a natural Veneration due
Not only from your Son, but for him too.
If an ill thought but comes into your head,
His preence ought to trike that Rebel dead,
And ev'n the Cradle-Infant tifle the mideed:
Like Hercules that in his Swadling-bands,
Two Serpents cruh'd between his Infant-hands.
Contemn not Children that are young and green,
They're old enough to imitate your in.
Beides with what Authority, what face
Can you reprove a Child for want of Grace?
And never think your elf how many grains
Mut be allow'd for your own hallow Brains?
'Tis a coniderable thing thou't done,
In getting of a true and lawful Son,
And adding to thy People's number one:
But that's not all; fit him for Peace or War,
The Clergys Pulpit, or the Lawyers Bar,
The Trademan's Shop, or honet Ploughman's Share.
Capacitate him for ome good Vocation,
The Service of his God, his King and Nation:
Ele to what purpoe is this Propagation?
The Vultures leave their Storehoue in the Fields,
And bring their young ones what that Store-houe yields.
Thee, as they older grow, hunt the ame Prey
From their Dams mouths they gobled t'other day.
Breed up your Children well, on that depends
Their future State; their good or their bad ends.
To other Vices Youth it elf is prone,
Sordidnes, that unnatural in, alone
Mut be inculcated, nor dares appear
Without the Mask of provident and evere.
By thee ininuations ground he gains,
Then wins the Field, and as a Tyrant reigns.
Nor is it trange the covetous Gripe hould be
Prais'd for the vertue of Frugality,
That all repect to his bald pate be pay'd,
A long experienc'd Artist in his Trade!
Whoe Furnace melts down the rich Ore of grounds!
Whoe Hammer beats out Pennies into Pounds!
Rare Alchymist! makes Money out of Mould!
Rare Midas! at a touch turns all to Gold!
Now he that do's this pinching Art profes,
Will only Brother Mier's practice bles,
And to his ilver God acribe true happines.
Him will he teach his Children to adore,
Tell them there is no Hell but to be poor.
That Heaven's Treaure lies in welling Bags,
The Mark of all Believers holy Rags.
(Vice has her Horn-book and ucceive Schools,

l.U: teps by method Rudiments and Rules.

div.l: The quickest Wits can't all at once be taught;
'Twas by degrees that Mithridates brought
Poyon to be no Poyon, but a cordial Draught.)
Here then he enters Children that are young,
Infants who have not yet well loos'd their liping tongue.
To little ordid things firt works their Brain,
Then to inatiable deires of gain.
No Maters but mut Graduates firt be,
Vice will not trut a Novice with the Key
That picks the Lock of her Philoophy.
See how the Wretch feeds on a buried Chest,
With Famine tarv'd, of golden Dreams poet!
See how he will his Servants of their Wages cheat!
And grutches every fragment that they eat!
Each fragment of dry crut, thÃ´ mouldy Bread,
What! Servants pamper'd? upon Sallads fed?
See how he locks up Cabbage, Sprouts, and Leeks!
A parted Onion, counting all the treaks!
See how wild rotten Olives he'll devour!
And quaff off dregs, Vinegar not o our!
On his own Birth-day, through a mall Crow's quill,
Foul tinking Oyl upon his Herbs ditil:
In raging Dog-Stars putrefying heat
Bring out a Mes of yeterdays minc'd Meat.
On Beds of Straw free choice of pennance lie,
The Swines Alcove is richer in the Stie.
Frugality! of a Sprat a Dinner makes;
For change of Raiment in the Dung-hill rakes.
Hang neaking! for a Feat in his best Cloaths,
He to the Beggar-boys a mumping goes.
In Winter runs to Bed before the Sun,
With Turfs and Ruh-lights he hall be undone.
But to what purpoe dot thou hoard up Pelf,
To ruin Prodigals, and cheat thy elf?
Why like the Bee thy time for nothing wat?
Nor of the fruits of all thy labours tat?
Honey for others luxury prepare?
A Beggar to the World, rich only to thy Heir.
Why be a Pimp to protitute thy tore?

Like Damocles hungry, like aAccording to the old Proverb, CynicÃ¨ vivere, (i. e.) canino more vivere, non ob impudentiam tantum ed & ob ordes. CynicÃ¨ < in non-Latin alphabet > . Torrentius.
Cynick poor.
Thy Soul is in a Dropie, and her thirt
Will then be atisfy'd when he can burst;
Ele pour down millions, till thou art not well,
But thy inordinate deires with Riches well,
Thy Sieve till gapes, and yet can nothing hold:
Craus his Cure was a weet Drench of melted Gold.
He that has leat of Wealth, deires it leat:
Content is happines: Enough's a Feat.
When two Farms will not do, a third you'll buy,
And ceae to purchae with Eternity.
You cannot ee a Neighbours Vineyard yield
A plenteous Vintage, or a fruitful Field
A better crop of Corn, but you mut long,
All my own, cries Extortion, right or wrong.
Such things are branded with notorious hame,
Loud ounds the Trumpet of an evil Fame.
Words are but wind, Riches to me are more,
Than to be call'd an honet man, but poor.
Yes,âWealth includes Properity and Eae,
Security from pains, peace, plenty, what you pleae!
'Tis trange to think how times degenerate!
That which was formerly a good Etate,
Goes for a trifle: Avarice o abounds,
The Prodigal's o profue, o rich the Mier's grounds.
Avarice, that woln Python! that Big-bellied Devil!
Who bore, and bred the Hydra of all evil.
That firt the ue of Steel and Poyon taught,
And bare-fac'd Murther into fahion brought:
For he that is o eager to be rich,
The more he rubs, the more he frets his Itch.
Pygmalion thus, of Homicides not the leat,
For Money lew a Brother and a Priest.
Live with your little hills and huts content,
'Tis better in your Bodies to be pent,
Than in your minds. Thus good Fabricius aid,
And Curius upon Rapes from Earthen Veels fed.
Thee Precepts did thoe reverend Sages give,
And by their practice taught us how to live.
He that the Yoke of Poverty can bear,
Nor under want inks deeper in depair:
Need not into the mouth of danger run,
Kill or be kill'd, at once made or undone.
This would the Ancients on their Children pres;
In Vertue only lies true happines.
Now the old covetous Gripe like Stentor bauls,
His Clerk at Midnight to his buines calls.
When the poor hivering Youngster carce can hold
His Pen, for the extremity of cold.
Rie! rie! you Sluggard, rie! Fitzherbert look,
Or carefully perue the Statute-book.
Copy out this Indenture; make a Deed,
And give me an account of what you read.
Quibbles have neither profit, nor delight,
Sophitry nothing tempting to invite:
Then give your mind to any other thing;
Preent a Panegyrick to the King:
Even to thee his bounty may extend,
A Mandate for a Fellowhip to lend.
For a Lieutenant's or a Captain's place,
Shew your broad Porter's houlders to his Grace.
Nine-pin Legs, Hairy Notrils, brawny Fit,
Be ure your Name'll be enter'd in the Lit.
But if you tremble when you hear a Gun,
And an Alarum rather makes you run,
Turn Chimny-weeper, Broker; never care
What Envy may object, but deal in any Ware;
For Gain mells weet, come it from what it will,
None will ay, Gain has an offenive mell.
He hugs his Gold that in the Kennel rakes,
Come it from Common-hore, or Sink, or Jakes.
None quetion whence a man grows rich, or how;
But money must be had, that we all know.
This every Infant learns of his old Dad,
Without it there's no Farthing to be had.
The little Boys and Girls thee Terms of Art,
Before their A b c, mut have by heart.
Why all this tir to teach a Child to be
No tranger to his Parents knavery?
Alas! there's no uch need for him to kis the Rod,
'Tis eaie following where his Father trod.
He's an apt Scholar, let him but alone,
When's corrupt Native Seeds full ripe are grown;
He cannot mis his Father's fatal Shelf,
Yet he has had no time to hew himelf.
When come to age, and in his hot mad blood,
And all the Doctor's practice undertood:
He'll wear, forwear, in Villany take delight,
Kill his rich Wife upon his Wedding-night;
And when the witty Rogue has done the feat,
Put a Jet on't, and laugh at the conceit:
I've purify'd my Gold, cries he, from dros,
And eparated my Lumber without los.
Whilt others weat and labour night and day,
By Sea and Land through unknown places tray,
He has a horter cut, a more compendious way.
'Twas but the letting a young Widdow blood,
That betwixt him and Mier's Heaven tood:
Now he'll be rich, and in a little time,
A new invention! and a rare deign!
The Reaon's evident, the cae is plain,
Sin comes into the world not without guilt, but pain.
You! no not you! ne're taught your Child to be
A ordid Hoarder, bae, or niggarlie:
What then? thoe covetous Seeds he had from thee.
They're naturally engrafted in his mind,
And he's a Mier not by Rule, but Kind.
A ordid Principle was in his blood,
And as he's yours, he'll never come to good.
He that commends Frugality, and allows
The leat upicious action in his houe,
Of Errour his own Judgment he convicts;
And whilt his Reaon thus he contradicts,
Youth of that lip an ill improvement make,
That as an univeral Licene take,
To cheat, defraud, and wear out an Etate,
Do any thing to be rich, do any thing to be great.
Give them an Inch, and they will take an Ell,
Blow you the Fire, their greedy Paions well,
They think they mut exceed, or ele they can't excel.
You've bred a Viper, that in time will eat
Through your own Bowels, and begin the cheat
Upon your elf: o the wild avage Bear
Will his own Mater firt to pieces tear.
Half his allowance he'll to Saffold give,
To know how long th' Old Man is like to live.
Gapes for your Gold, and cures every Knell,
That he mitakes to be your Paing-bell.
At length impatient for your lingring doom,
He will not let it oft and fairly come:
Saves Hell the trouble, and will Fate foretal,
Be Executioner, and have at all.
From your own fleh and bloud you're forc'd to guard your Throat,
And carry up and down an Antidote.
Hail Democritus! tune up your Lungs for mirth!
Here's the Ludibrium of Heaven and Earth,
That might your laughter for your lives engros,
To ee refined Clay thus hoard up dros.
With pains, and care, and danger, grap up tore,
With pains, and care, and danger, keep it more,
But in reverion rich, emphatically poor!
The Mier's Life's a pleaant Comedy!
None o ridiculous a Fool as he!
The Dancer on the Ropes les laughter makes,
H'as better grounds for what he undertakes;
By hazarding his neck he gets his Bread,
And Nature to utain, ventures his head:
Like Nero, you for Mounts of Golden Ore,
To tumble up and down on ilver floor.
See what vat throngs of Veels plough the Main,
And all to find out unknown Worlds of Gain.
By Hercules his Pillars take their rounds,
Shoot Gulfs, like Remus leap o'er Nature's bounds.
'Tis worth the while to run the rique of Fate,
Stare Death i'th' face, to raie a vat Etate.
He that to this degree of confidence arrives,
ThÃ´ Pluto be his Guide, by Pluto thrives;
'Tis not one Fury, nor one Devil drives.
He that one plank from Hell can lie and leep,
With both the Indies loaden, dance along the deep,
ThÃ´ he to ave his Pure may well forbear
Revenge upon his Cloaths, and pulling off his Hair:
Yet Bedlam for him groans, Bedlam ne're had
One under her correction half o mad.
A Storm comes hovering, and Phoebus hrouds
His watry Rays under ecliping Clouds;
Cimmerian darknes falls upon the Air,
Black as th' Abys, and hopeles as Depair;
Flahes of Lightning's all the light is given,
And Thunder-bolts rowl o're the Plains of Heaven;
Yet cries the Scrape: Trust my Atrologie,
Clear is the lowring Sky, and calm the troubled Sea.
Thee are but Lambent flames, what men afraid of light?
Of harmles Crackers in a Summers night?
Which a corcht Air and ultry heat produce?
Come hoie your Sails, and let your Rudders looe,
Let frowning Heaven care us then no more,
The God will ave me whom I till adore.
Blind! vain! unhappy man! perhaps to night
His Soul to Charon goes, and his delight
To Pluto offers him a Sacrifice:
The Conj'rer o by his Familiar dies.
Methinks I ee him trugling hard for breath,
Oh, how he gnaws his Pure, and grinds his teeth!
And that mut be his life, or that mut be his death!
If Fortune favour, he comes afe to hore,
Whom all the World could not uffice before,
Nor Tagus nor Pactolus with their Golden Ore.
Now without Houe or Home, ready to tarve,
Torn Rags to hide his nakednes will erve,
Fragments of mouldy Bread, and craps of Meat,
Which Beggars proffer'd, would refue to eat,
Go down o chearfully, and oh! a Crut's o weet!
Oh! the delicious Fare of Bread and Cheee!
Oh! how the Mier begs upon his knees!
To get a Farthing do's his mieries relate,
And prove his Shipwrack by Certificate:
And this is to be rich! and this is to be great!
Wealth with uch trouble and uch care procur'd,
From Fire and Thieves, turns but to little Gains;
Nothing can recompence eternal pains.
Cân that rich poor man, can take no ret,
With lavih Fears like Mill-tones on his breat;
Mut have three turdy Fellows always on their guard,
And for their ue Engines and Arms prepar'd.
Yet jealous Whims his Eyes till waking keep,
Poor Cân cannot take a wink of leep.
There's no rude hand would touch the Cynick's Den,
If burnt or broken by malicious men;
He would another Tub to morrow make,
Or out of this a tately Lodging take.
This Alexander knew, and curs'd his Fate,
That cat his Lot o much below the State
Of wie Diogenes, Diogenes the Great!
Small was the Shell, great the Inhabitant!
Who nothing had, and yet did nothing want!
Happier than he that fain would befor ever known,
Monarch, and God, and make the World his own:
Whoe Glories would to Dangers oon betray,
Whoe Dangers would his Glories far outweigh.
He that to Widom's Light conforms his Soul,
Can never loe his way, nor mis the Goal.
No Deity is wanting to the Wie,
For Prudence is the best of Deities.
Which he that ingle harbours in his breat,
In her alone comprehends all the ret.
Fortune! thy Godhead o implor'd below,
Only to Fools and Mad-men thou dot owe.
Thou dot no God-like Attributes partake,
A Demy-Goddes of a Humane make!
If any one will accept of my Advice,
To know jut what Ingredients may uffice
To make up a good honet Livelihood,
Too little by Pretenders undertood:
Firt q. . of Meat,
To keep out Cold and Hunger, freely eat
Of temp'rate Socrates his wholom Dih,
And take an ounce or two of Cowly's Wih.
For Meditation ake, and for your health,
To Epicurus Garden, and there ee
Nature in every Variety.
There every day ome time for tudy hould be pent,
Eat freely of the only Fruit, Content.
Nature and Widom always ay the ame,
Nature and Widom here do differ but in name.
Still thirts your Soul as if your Heart would break,
Another Julep then more uual make,
Two thouand pound for a Pearl-Cordial take.
Still can you make a Face? contract a Frown?
As if you could not get your Pect'ral Potion down?
Once more your former Cordial then repeat,
And add four thouand pound to make it weet.
Still take you up a prejudice againt this Receipt?
Then all the Wealth that both the Indies boat,
To this, were thrown away, and meerly lost:
Would never atisfie your damn'd exces,
Nor in the leat contribute to true Happines.

q.l: âOmnis enim res,
Virtus, fama, decus, divina humanaque pulchris
Divitiis parent! quas qui contruxerit, ille
Clarus erit, fortis, jutus! &c.
Horat. Sat. lib. 2. . 3.

div.head: An EPIGRAM. To Mr. H. Northcote of Exeter-Colledge, Oxon.
The Happy Mier.
div.l: WHy hould we to this World our Souls enlave,
That never yet true atisfaction gave,
That has no happines but in the Grave?
She throws us Pleaures only to bereave,
To decay Subject, Subject to deceive,
They us, We them mut once for ever leave.
Our Title's good no longer than our Life,
Our Friends inherit little ele but Strife.
In death the Mier's only happy found,
Who goes t' enjoy his Treaure under ground.

div.head: An EPIGRAM. In praie of John Pig's Diminutive Noe, in imitation of the Emperour Trajan's.
To Mr. Frederick Colman.
div.l: WEllâall the Dyal-makers are undone!
Let Pig but turn his Nole to the Sun,
'Twill erve for both Steeple and Weather-cock,
And on his Teeth tell Travellers what's a Clock.

div.head: Another out of Ammianus. To Mr. T. Woolley.
Concerning John Pig's Mountainous Noe and Quick-ilver Feet.
div.l: WIth both his hands Pig cannot night his Snout,
But he mut go near half a mile about;
So long the Promontory of his Noe!
So hort, o lender, are his Petty-toes!
Nor can he wind his horny Trunk with eae,
Noânor, to peak the truth, hear himelf neeze.
So far that Marrow-bone's ditant from his Ears,
He has not aid, God bles me, for this fifty years.
I'th' trength of uch a Staff, Pig (as they talk)
May well from London to New-Catle take a walk.

div.head: To a young Lady reading the eventh Vere of the firt Chapter of Proverbs.

epigraph.q: The fear of the Lord is the beginning of knowledge, &c.

div.head: To Idera.
div.l: WHilt the Contents of this one Vere
So paionately you reheare,
In it we comprehended find
The perfect Copy of your Mind.
You teach us, and inform us too,
What we hould, and what you do.
This is your Noon, our early Dawn,
In miniature your Picture drawn.
Compendious Hitory of your Life:
In Vertue your victorious trife:
Like wretling Jacob, whilt you halt,
You make us bluh at our Revolt.
Here in this Looking-glas we ee
The Beauties of your Soul, what we
Like you, and for your ake deire to be.
We came, and heard, and were undone!
With earthly flames the Fire begun,
When heavenly too conpir'd to joyn
United Forces, humane and divine:
High Winds more dangerous than they;
In vain our Engines then we play:
When the chief Catle is burnt down,
'Tis more than time that we urrender up the Town.

div.head: To his Valentine Hemiera, Madam A. R.
div.l: WEllâFortune! protrate at thy feet
I'll do my Penance in a Sheet;
For want of ight I call'd thee blind,
All thy Revenge was to be kind.
Amongt the Lots upon thy Throne,
Thou Omnipreent at't alone.
I laid my trembling hand on all,
And as I took them, let them fall.
But confident in thee my Guide,
That which did hrinking from me lide,
I gently pret, and it comply'd.
With this encouragement I draw,
But when the happy Name I aw,
Ye Gods! with what amazement truck!
I kis'd my Valentine and blet my Luck?
A. firt was offer'd to my ight,
With a weet relih to invite
My over-eager Appetite.
My Soul reolv'd on life or death,
Of an aupicious ALPHA full, took breath.
Then to uck Honey out of Love,
To the ripe Roe did next remove.
Her he rob'd of all her Red,
And on her fragrant weetnes fed.
My raviht Soul her tation took
Here, and durt no further look.
R was the Centre of my Heart:
R my only vital part:
R pleas'd and atisfy'd my tat:
As Roes beautiful, as Lillies chat.
Pythagoras may his y admire,
'Tis R that ets my Heart on fire:
R never yet came out of time;
R is my Reaon and my Rhime.
R o weetly runs along,
R the burden of my Song.
But ince R at a ditance only darts a Smile,
Which at a ditance mut recoil;
My Vow I firt will end, before I bring
In peron a Religious Offering.
Here this I abent lay before her Shrine,
Kies by proxy to communicate my deign,
Remember Eater, and Good Morrow, Valentine.

div.head: To Idera. Who would not be een to teal a Look from Duerates, by turning her back.

q.l: Malo me Galatea petit laciva puella,
Et fugit ad alices, & e cupit ante videri.

lg.l: WHy, Cupid, thus at hide and eek?
Why all thoe Bluhes on your Cheek?
Are you aham'd that priviledge to give,
That man hould ee your face, and live?
Or would you at a ditance keep,
And never kis Endymion but aleep?
Are you afraid that hould your Sun hine bright,
Whilt Duerates only prays for Light,
My dazled Eyes with too much glory blind,
Earth and my elf hould hardly find?
Or that I hould to Phaeton's Wih apire,
To et my little World on fire?
Why o cruel? why o coy?
Never, never to enjoy?
Have we profan'd Love's Deity all this while,
Ah, Madam! now to teal a Smile?
This is with time to kep Virginity,
And take the meaure of Eternity.

q.l: Utraque formoa et: operoae cultibus ambae:
Artibus in dubio et haec it, an illa, prior.
Pulerior hÃ¢ illa et, haec et quoque pulcrior illÃ¢:
Et magis haec nobis, & magis illa placet.
Quid geminas, Erycina, meos ine fine dolores?
Nonne erat in curas una puella atis?

lg.l: TEll me, individual Pair!
Beyond a Mediocrity of Fair!
Whoe Beauties Heaven can carce improve;
Whom I was born to love:
How hall I divide my Heart?
Tell me, ye that have there a double part.
Diviion multiplies my pains;
Ditraction lays more weight upon my Chains.
When tately Idera I ee,
I think of Jove's high love for Semele:
Love that in Thunder and in Lightning came;
Oh! my Soul burns to die by uch a flame.
Hemiera, by Nature kind,
Has Idera's face wrought in her mind.
Which Idera's imperious Eyes controul.
Idera with a haughty Air,
Affects to be thought omething more than fair.
Hemiera is as good, as Idera's great:
High, courtly Idera! made for me and State.
Hemiera's melancholy Face
Has les Charms, but more of Grace:
Does both my Pity and my Love,
Thoe Springs of my Affections move.
Idera's comely Winter's pride,
With Heperian Fruits upply'd;
Other proud Summers dare not vy,
Nor in her preence wear their Livery.
Hemiera's Autumn's youthful Bloud
Does ooner bloom, ooner bud,
Than other Springs with April-howers,
Diolv'd into ubiquity of Flowers.
Idera on point of Honour tands,
My Soul by right of conquest he demands:
All that of my elf is mine,
I to Hemiera reign.
But if Idera, with didain,
Would make me fear, not love her, 'tis in vain:
She'll repent, when 'tis too late:
I'll ooner undergo Saguntum's Fate.
Me mea diperdat nullo prohibente puella,
Si atis una potest: i minus una, duae.

div.head: To P. P. being to run a Race after Dinner.
div.l: SHarp Gormandizer! heavy-heel'd Racer! run
With nimble Chaps; and to upply them, eat
A hearty Meal with your defective Feet:
By this exchange the Race is eas'ly won.

div.head: An Epigram out of Alphaeus Mitylenaeus. To Mr. Humphry Lind.
div.l: WE envy not, Philaphelus! the Great,
Nor would pull down their Pinacles of State:
Nor prop them up, projecting to apire:
A Competency only we deire.
Yet Poverty we would not hug as uch,
Let ne quid nimis we hould love too much.

div.head: Another. To Mr. Denham.
Diogenes in his Kingdom.
div.l: WHen the old Cynicks hade with Croeus met,
He mil'd to ee the meager Monarch fret;
And thus accoted himâBut why o pale?
What, doos the Yellow Jaundice till prevail?
NoâCroeus! noâfor all your earthly tore,
You, call'd to an account, not I, am poor.
All that I had, here I have with me brought,
You've travell'd to another World with nothing fraught.

div.head: An EPITAPH on old Oliver.
To Mr. Andrew Snapes.
div.l: LIe light, thou Earth, on Noll's oft Noddle;
His Corps in Putrefaction coddle.
Lie light, that Dogs may mell and rave
To cratch the Tyrant from his Grave:
That Dogs may lay his Carcae bare,
And Mees of his Mummy tear.
Dogs his polluted Gelly up,
And dig the Devil's Relicks up.

div.head: A Greek EPIGRAM. A hort Life and a weet. To his dear Friend Mr. Edw. Taylour.
div.l: MY Fortune-tellers this ill Caution give,
Oh! 'tis ad news, I have not long to live.
So ay my Stars and they, but what care I?
Sooner or later, all mut die.
But let us tay and drink before we go,
'Tis a way I never went, and do not know.
Bacchus is well acquainted with the Road,
And never goes this Stage without a load.
On uch a Hore if I below can ride,
Why hould I go on foot without a Guide?

div.head: To Mr. Henry Palmer, going to Sea.
div.l: THrow not my life away, of your own free,
'Tis tender Mother Earth, but Stepdame Sea.

div.head: To Mr. Butler.
A Greek EPIGRAM.
div.l: I In the flower of my days was poor,
Now Age comes creeping with unwelcome tore.
Unhappy till! I can't my elf enjoy:
My hopes of Heaven two Extreams detroy;
And will not let me my deires fulfil,
Then want of Power, now a want of Will.

div.head: To his dear Friend Mr. Will. Percival. That Poetry is Witchcraft.
div.l: WIth Legion ure the Mues are poet,
That play the Devil in every inpir'd breast.
What Epidemick Plague runs in mens Veins?
What an eternal dribling of the Brains?
My greatet Enemy I'd wih no wore,
Than th' Itch of Scribling, and a Poet's Cure.

div.head: Antipater's Epitaph upon Homer.
To Mr. John Penneck.
div.l: HEre lies (with reverence to his acred Name)
The Hero's Herald, and the Trump of Fame,
The World's Poetick Tongue, the Mues Flame.
The Prophet of the Gods, and Greece's Sun,
Homer that comprehends them all in one.

div.head: To Mr. Nat. Smith.
On a covetous old Mier, a religious Gripe.
div.l: Wâthe Mier's Treaurer, old and grey,
For fear of want, would make himelf away:
His Houe in order et, he falls to Pray'r;
Then makes his Will, and leaves himelf ole Heir.
But what a pity 'tis his labour's lost,
At leat a Halter will a Farthing cot.
Noâhe had rather Hell's Election wait,
Than buy a Hanging at o dear a rate.

div.head: To Mr. King.
A Greek Epigram againt the Atrologers.
div.l: HOW cant thou, Atrius, Heaven and Earth urvey?
Thou little crum of a mall lump of Clay!
Firt know thy elf, thy own Dimenions find,
And take the narrow compas of thy Mind.
For if thou cant not meaure uch a Clod,
What wouldt thou do with all the wondrous works. of God?

div.head: To Mr. Hen. Fane.
div.l: POor foolih Dick, tung by his Brother Gnat,
Jump'd out of Bed to fetch old Proctor's Cat.
Mouer, thÃ´ a brave Souldier, lot his port,
For Mouer could not peak the Language of the Court;
Nor undertand what formal Prician aid
In Babel's Tongue, thÃ´ othewie well bred.
With that Don Quixot's Rival would engage

Gingerbread Gentleman; this is applicable either to his hapes, or the old tory of his Weekly-Allowance, which was a Gingerbread pair of Gloves, and a Gingerbread Ring. Gingerbread Gentleman in warlike rage,
Rapt out a terrible dimidiate Oath,
And in his own defence, Sir, challeng'd both:
His Rapier out of ruty Scabbard drew;
But Pus, who his undaunted Courage knew,
All on a weat, down Stairs like Lightning flew.
Nor hall he o ecape by all the Gods,
(Says Sancho Pancho Dick) for two to one is odds.
Spaniard tied neck and heels he laid upon his back,
And hung him by his Whiskers on the Rack.
Friend Gnat! (quoth he) thÃ´ now I'm almot pent,
Yet thy affront I cannot but reent.
All night I'll make thee at a ditance keep,
Put on revenge when I put off my leep.
This aid, as merciful as he was tout,
Knight Errant put hisSuch as his Worhip made his boast, the King and his Father only burnt. Royal Candle out.
(Candles Traditional, o long, o large, o white,
Worthy to give the King and Dicky light;

Worthy to make aOn his Birth-day at night he cut a pound of Candles in halves, and etting them in a Ring, light them, and danc'd round them, inging a Hymn to his Mue Clio, whom he worhips in the form of a waxen Cow, and acrifices to her, to the end he may inpire him more fully. Fairy-ring on Birth-day-night.
Fit Torches for a Sacrifice to Clio,
A heavenly Mue made of a waxen Io.)
And then a Hymn Poean the Champion ang,
Defy'd Gnat, Bug, or Flea, all the Backbiting Gang.
Afraid that they hould hear, in Whipers aid, Good Night!
And hugg'd himelf to think they could not ee to bite.

lg.l: I Lais! once a heavenly Whore!
But now thoe happy days are o'er!
Sweet Lais! Divine Lais! now no more.
This Looking-glas to Venus give,
My too true Repreentative:
Since what I am I would not ee,
Since what I was I cannot be.

q.l: Me verÃ² primum dulces ante omnia Muae
(Quarum acra fero ingenti perculus amore)
